Abstract 

 

C and Sr isotope compositions of carbonate rocks from the intracontinental São 

Francisco basin can track ocean connections and restriction. The lower three formations of the 

Bambuí Group can be grouped into three chemostratigraphic intervals (CI), recording 

different evolution stages of the basin. Lowermost CI-1 comprises the basal cap carbonates of 

the Sete Lagoas Formation displaying an initial C negative excursion, followed by a coeval C 

and Sr positive excursions (?
13

C values from -5 to 0‰ and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from 0.7074 to 

0.7082) in 10 m of stratigraphic record. It marks a change from a restricted shallow basin 

influenced by freshwater to a basin connected to external seawaters due to marine 

transgression. CI-2 comprises carbonates of the middle portion of the Sete Lagoas Formation 

with ?
13

C values around 0‰ and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7082 that matches those observed 

worldwide for the Late Ediacaran. It records the onset of a Gondwana sea pathway connecting 

several epicontinental basins, allowing migration of index-fossil Cloudina sp. Uppermost CI-

3 starts after a major positive excursion in the ?
13

C values reaching +16‰ and a steepened 

decrease of 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios to 0.7075 which are lower than those expected for the Ediacaran-

Cambrian boundary. This interval comprises the upper Sete Lagoas, Serra de Santa Helena 

and Lagoa do Jacaré formations and records the end of the connection of the São Francisco 

basin to the Gondwana sea pathway setting a restricted epeiric sea. Restriction was probably 

caused by Late Ediacaran uplifting of orogenic belts surrounding the basin. Other West 

Gondwana Cloudina bearing units also display the same mismatch in the Sr isotope ratios, 

mailto:gustavomps@yahoo.com.br


74 

 

suggesting that the establishment of intracontinental basins inside large continental masses 

may challenge the use of isotope chemostratigraphy for interbasinal correlations. 

 

Keywords: Chemostratigraphy, carbonate rocks, São Francisco Basin, Bambuí Group, West 

Gondwana 

 

1. Introduction 

 

The São Francisco basin comprises siliciclastic and carbonate units that cover a 

massive area of the São Francisco Craton in east central Brazil (Fig. 1). In its southern sector, 

the basin is composed of the conglomerate, siltite and carbonate rocks of the basal Carrancas 

Formation (Uhlein et al., 2012, 2016) and the overlying pelitic-carbonate rocks of the Bambuí 

Group (Dardenne, 1978). The knowledge about this last unit has undergone many changes 

over the past decade, which are crucial for the understanding of the assembly of the 

Gondwana continent during the Neoproterozoic era and the paleoenvironmental changes in 

the ocean and inland seas that ultimately led to the biota evolution during the Ediacaran-

Cambrian transition. 

Formerly, the Bambuí Group was believed to be one of the post-glacial 

Neoproterozoic units that would record the extreme shifts in the planet?s climate proposed by 

the Snowball Earth hypothesis (Hoffman et al., 1998; Hoffman and Schrag, 2002), whether 

Sturtian (Babinski et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007) or Marinoan (Caxito et al., 2012; 

Alvarenga et al., 2014), given its negative carbon isotope signature and the fact that it sits 

atop glacial deposits of the Jequitaí, Macaúbas and Carrancas formations (Pflug et al., 1975; 

Rocha-Campos et al., 1981; Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Martins-Neto et al., 1999; Uhlein et 

al., 1999; Cukrov et al., 2005; Vieira et al., 2007). But recent geochronological and fossil data 

from the base of the Bambuí Group showed that in fact we are dealing with a younger 

geological record. Warren et al. (2014) described at the basal sequence of the Sete Lagoas 

Formation, lowermost unit of the Bambuí Group, metazoan fossil Cloudina sp., which is 

dated elsewhere at 550-542 Ma (Grotzinger et al., 2000). Paula-Santos et al. (2015) dated 

detrital zircons (U-Pb method) from marlstone layers interbedded with limestones of the same 

unit and set its maximum depositional age at about 560 Ma. These new data imply that most 

of the Bambuí Group was probably deposited around or after the Ediacaran-Cambrian limit, 

following the closure of the Adamastor Ocean to the east of the Craton. Therefore it records 

the evolution of an epeiric sea that existed in the very core of the Gondwana continent (Paula-



75 

 

Santos et al., 2015), scenario also pointed in some other publications (Martins and Lemos, 

2007; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). This geotectonic framework is important to 

comprehend the meaning of the isotope record of the carbonate rocks of this unit, especially 

of the basal Sete Lagoas Formation (Fig. 2). 

The Sete Lagoas Formation is subdivided into two depositional sequences (Fig. 2; 

Vieira et al., 2007). The first sequence would have started in the aftermath of a glacial event 

and comprises a shallowing upward succession with carbonate displaying seafloor 

sedimentation features such as aragonite pseudomorphes, carbonate mud and cement, in the 

Sete Lagoas city area (Vieira et al., 2007) and with a pink meter-thick dolostone throughout 

the basin (Santos et al., 2004; Alvarenga et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012). In the studied area 

the carbonates are base truncated with the basement and display a progressive increasing in 

?
13

C values -4.5 to 0‰ (Vieira et al., 2007). The pink dolostones and other sections were the 

carbonates are atop the basal diamictites display initially a decreasing in the C isotope values 

from -3 to -5‰ before the increase towards 0‰ (Alvarenga et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; 

Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). Such isotopic and sedimentary features are typical of cap 

carbonates found elsewhere in the globe (Grotzinger and Knoll, 1995; Kennedy, 1996; 

Hoffman and Schrag, 2002). Upward, the sequence displays light gray carbonates deposited 

in a high energy platform with ?
13

C values within a narrow interval around 0‰. After a basin 

drowning, an abrupt shift in the C isotope values of regional expression (Santos et al., 2004) 

marks the start of the second sequence composed by another shallowing upward succession 

with low energy dark carbonates displaying unusually high ?
13

C values up to +16‰ (Iyer et 

al., 1995).  

Such important variations in the carbon isotope record contrast with the steady 

evolution of the Sr record reported for most of the Bambuí Group above the cap carbonate 

succession, which shows a sharp increase in 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from 0.7074 to 0.7082 (Babinski 

et al., 2007). Above the cap carbonates the most pristine 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios are considered to be 

between 0.7074-0.7075 (Alvarenga et al., 2007; 2014; Babinski et al., 2007; Misi et al., 2007; 

Caxito et al., 2012; Paula-Santos et al., 2015; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). These ratios clearly 

contrast with the ratios higher than 0.7080 predicted for the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary in 

the Sr evolution curves for the Neoproterozoic-Cambrian Ocean (e.g. Melezhik et al., 2001; 

Halverson et al., 2010; Kuznetsov et al., 2013). Such discrepancy has been interpreted as due 

to the restriction of the epeiric sea due to the uplifting of orogenic belts surrounding the São 

Francisco Craton by that time, leading to a different evolution from the global ocean (Paula-



76 

 

Santos et al., 2015). This scenario seems plausible when analyzing the Gondwana 

paleogeography at ca. 540 Ma (Fig. 1; Alkmin et al., 2006) and also cast doubt on the global 

significance of the isotope record of the Bambuí Group. Searching for this answer is crucial to 

understand the chemical and biological changes on the Bambuí sea during the Ediacaran-

Cambrian limit. 

In this work we show through new and previously published C, O and Sr isotope data 

that the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios recorded in the carbonate rocks of the Bambuí Group covariate with 

the great changes in the carbon isotope record. For that, we reevaluate the Sr isotope data to 

select the most pristine ratios. Considering all available data, the Bambuí Group can be 

subdivided into three different chemostratigraphic stages marking the onset and demise of the 

connection of the São Francisco Basin to the global ocean isotope reservoir. Such a mismatch 

between the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr found locally and the global isotope curves is also recorded in other 

Cloudina bearing carbonate units of the West Gondwana (Kawashita et al., 1999; Gaucher et 

al., 2009; Frei et al., 2011; Aubet et al., 2012). In fact, the onset of intracontinental marine 

basins in this large continental mass may have created environments where local conditions 

could have surpassed global events in terms of importance to the buildup of their isotope 

reservoirs. If so, it represents a challenge for using isotope chemostratigraphy as an 

interbasinal correlation tool in such settings, and at the same time, precludes the use of 

isotope data of such units to reconstruct the isotope composition of the global ocean. 

 

2. Geological setting 

 

The São Francisco basin deposits cover an area of more than 300.000 km
2
 of the 

homonymous craton (Fig. 1). The Archean-Paleoproterozoic basement is exposed at the 

southern and northeast areas of the craton (Teixeira et al., 2000; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 

2012). 

The Neoproterozoic-Cambrian deposits of the basin comprise the sparse glacial units 

of mainly continental origin of the Jequitaí Formation at the base (Rocha-Campos et al., 1981; 

Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Martins-Neto and Hercos, 2002) and the overlying marine 

siliciclastic-carbonate sediments of the Bambuí Group (Fig. 2, Dardenne, 1978; Vieira et al., 

2007; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012; Kuchenbecker et al., 2013). Despite tectonic 

discontinuities (e.g., thrust faults along craton limits) the glacial unit has equivalents on the 

mobile belts that surround the craton: the Macaúbas Group on the Araçuaí orogen and the Ibiá 



77 

 

Group on the Brasília Belt (Uhlein et al., 1999; Dardenne, 2000; Martins-Neto et al., 2001; 

Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011a; Babinski et al., 2012). 

According to some authors, the Bambuí Group deposits record a marine transgression 

in a foreland basin developed on the craton as a result of the Brasília and Araçuaí belts 

overload (Martins-Neto et al., 2001; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). The unit outcrops 

throughout the cratonic area and the western Brasília belt, but its deposits are not known on 

the eastern Araçuaí belt (Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2008, 2011a, Babinski et al., 2012). In the 

studied area, the Bambuí Group is in sharp contact with the Archean-Paleoproterozoic 

basement in most locations, but in some localities such as São José da Lapa and Inhaúma it 

overlies the Carrancas Formation (Fig. 1). This last unit comprises conglomerate and siltite, 

considered to be also an equivalent of the Jequitaí Formation on the cratonic area (Dardenne, 

1978; Vieira et al., 2007) or the base of the Bambuí Group (Caxito et al., 2012). The 

Neoproterozoic-Cambrian cover is separated from the basement by shear zones with well 

developed foliation and stretching lineation marked by calcite, mica and chlorite. The 

metamorphism in this zone is low graded, but non-metamorphosed well preserved carbonate 

layers are found between shear zones and far from the marginal fold and thrust belts. 

The Bambuí Group is subdivided into five units (Dardenne, 1978) namely, from base to top 

(Fig. 2): (i) Sete Lagoas Formation, which comprises limestone and dolostones with 

interbedded pelitic layers (thickness ? 500 m); (ii) Serra de Santa Helena Formation, mainly 

composed of shale and siltstone with interbedded limestone and sandstone (640 m); (iii) 

Lagoa do Jacaré Formation, which displays limestone, siltstone and marlstones (350 m); (iv) 

Serra da Saudade Formation, constituted of siltstone, green shale and subordinately limestone 

(100 m); and (v) Três Marias Formation, composed of arkosic sandstone and siltstone (100 

m). Unit thicknesses given here are based on Iglesias and Uhlein (2009). 

 



78 

 

 

 

 

Fig. 1 – Geological maps of the West Gondwana at ca. 540 Ma, the São Francisco Craton (modified from Alkmim et al., 2006) and the studied area with 

locations of the sampled sections from the Bambuí Group. SJL: São José da Lapa, IN: Inhaúma, FN: Funilândia, LV: Linha Verde, SC: Sopé da Cruz, GPP: 

Gruta do Peri-Peri, HV: Haras Veredas, MT: Matozinhos, CB: Capim Branco, SL: Sete Lagoas, SH: Serra de Santa Helena carbonate samples, FAS: Fazenda 

Água Santa, LJ: Lagoa do Jacaré 



79 

 

The isotope record of the Bambuí Group comprises mainly data from the basal Sete 

Lagoas Formation (Iyer et al., 1995; Santos et al., 2000, 2004; Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014; 

Babinski et al., 2007; Misi et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Paula-Santos et 

al., 2015; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016), owing to its carbonate dominated constitution. The 

dataset shows three distinct intervals with marked ?
13

C values (V-PDB) along the unit?s 

stratigraphy. These intervals are referred here as chemostratigraphic intervals (CI; Fig. 2), but 

each one presents peculiar lithological and sedimentological characteristics too (Schöll, 1967; 

Vieira et al., 2007). The basal CI-1 is composed of carbonate displaying very negative carbon 

isotope values, as low as -4.5‰ in the base truncated deposits of the studied area (Vieira et 

al., 2007). In the most complete sections elsewhere, these carbonates exhibit an initial 

negative excursion from -3 to -5‰ (Alvarenga et al., 2007; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). It 

represents the cap carbonate successions that typically overly Cryogenian glacial deposits, 

displaying sedimentary features found in other cap carbonates elsewhere in the world such as 

aragonite fans, carbonate mud and cement crusts (Grotzinger and Knoll, 1995; Kennedy, 

1996; Hoffman and Schrag, 2002). The negative values increase upward until the CI-2, which 

displays light gray carbonates with high energy sedimentary structures and ?
13

C values 

varying in a narrow range around 0‰. In some portions of the basin, this interval can reach 

values up to +4‰, starting a positive excursion, which is characteristic of the upper units. The 

uppermost CI-3 comprises dark carbonate with low energy sedimentary structures (planar 

lamination, massive carbonate) and starts after a major shift in the carbon isotope record 

registering a positive excursion with values starting around 4‰ and locally reaching values as 

high as 16‰ (Iyer et al., 1995). This abrupt shift in the carbon isotopic signal has regional 

expression and can be used as a stratigraphic marker (Santos et al., 2004). 



80

Sete Lagoas Formation. 



81 

 

Despite these great variations on the C isotope record, only the basal cap carbonates 

have shown significant 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratio fluctuations. Babinski et al. (2007) recognized a fast 

increase in the Sr isotope ratios from 0.7074 to 0.7082 at the base of the Sete Lagoas 

Formation. For CI-2 and CI-3 the best preserved 
87

Sr/
86

Sr are considered to be always within 

0.7074-0.7075 (Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014; Misi et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Paula-

Santos et al., 2015; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016), even across the major shift in the ?
13

C values 

on the transition of the intervals. Likewise, the best preserved 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios of carbonates 

from Lagoa do Jacaré Formation are also considered to be around 0.7074-0.7075 (Misi et al., 

2007). This fact probably originates due to a diagenesis screening process that involves an 

integrated analysis from carbonates of CI-2 and CI-3 in the same diagrams. This often leads to 

discard Sr data from CI-2 as they are usually more radiogenic and depleted in Sr (Alvarenga 

et al., 2007, 2014; Misi et al., 2007; Paula-Santos et al., 2015; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). 

This work offers a new approach on such evaluation. As the major shift in C isotopes suggests 

a significant change in the São Francisco Basin evolution, we screen for post-depositional 

alterations by analysing data from CI-2 and CI-3 separately. 

 

2.1. Studied area and sections 

 

Eleven sections in the southern sector of the São Francisco basin that comprise the 

three CI (posteriorly checked with C isotope analysis) were described and sampled. All the 

studied outcrops exhibit E-W interstratal sliding lineations. Sections IN, FN, LV, SL and HV 

are the same studied by Guacaneme (2015).  

The CI-1 is represented by section SJL (São José da Lapa) located on the MG-424 

road at São José da Lapa city (Fig. 1). The section is 3 m thick (Fig. 3) and composed of 0.5 

m of mudstone with aragonite pseudomorphes at the base grading to impure limestones to the 

top (Fig. 5b). These carbonate rocks tectonically overly oligomitic (clasts of leucogranite, 

quartz veins and carbonate clasts) diamictite of the Carrancas Formation. 

Five sections of CI-2 were studied. At the easternmost part of the studied area (Fig. 1), 

sections LV (Linha Verde) and FN (Funilândia) comprise largely deformed limestones and 

dolostones with siliciclastic content as high as 10% (Fig. 3). These rocks display E-W to NE-

SW schistosity parallel to sedimentary lamination marked by oriented crystals of sericite. 

Quartz and calcite veins with boudins are frequent between carbonate layers which in turn 

may appear folded. Sections located at the west part of the studied area are much less 

deformed. The IN section near Inhaúma city (Fig. 1) starts with 9 m of monomitic diamictite 



82 

 

of the Carrancas Formation deposited on a basement valley. Clasts are exclusively 

leucogranite from the valley walls with sub-angular to sub-rounded shape and sizes ranging 

from 2 to 20 cm (largest side; Fig. 5a). The greenish matrix is composed of silt and sand 

quartz and feldspars with rare carbonate cement. The diamictite is covered by 20 m of fine 

laminated siltite. Two pink massive 1 m thick limestone layers interbedded in siltite were 

described in a basement high half kilometre away to the south of the diamictite occurrence. 

Grey impure limestone of CI-2 (5-7% of detrital content) covers the siltites and displays 

mainly plane parallel to planar truncated lamination with some minor cross stratification. The 

transition from Carrancas to Sete Lagoas formations is marked by the gradual increase of the 

carbonate content to the top. The SC (Sopé da Cruz) section in the east of Sete Lagoas city 

(Fig. 2) comprises 36 m of gray impure limestones (5% of detrital content) displaying mainly 

truncated lamination with cross stratification at some levels (Fig 4c). Upward, these carbonate 

rocks progressively show more planar lamination, darker gray colour and less detrital content 

indicating the transition to CI-3. The GPP section (Gruta do Peri-Peri, Fig. 2) comprises 

carbonate rocks from both CI-2 and CI-3 (Fig. 3). The first 22 m exhibits light grey limestone 

with up to 10% detrital content and some dolomitised layers. After two meters of vegetation 

cover, dark grey limestone crops out displaying planar lamination and 10 cm thick non 

continuous levels of oolites. A 50 cm thick marlstone layer is found at the base of these dark 

carbonate rocks.  

Four additional sections of CI-3 in the Sete Lagoas Formation were described (Fig. 4). 

From east to west: HV (Haras Veredas), MT (Matozinhos), CB (Capim Branco) and SL (Sete 

Lagoas) sections (Fig. 1). In a general approach, all these sections display monotonous dark 

grey to black limestone with planar lamination (Fig. 5d). The easternmost SL section also 

comprises massive limestone and a 30 cm shale layer close to its top. In all sections, oil stains 

were frequent indicating maturation of organic matter and migration of hydrocarbons (Fig. 

5e). Three dark carbonate layers interbedded within the Serra de Santa Helena Formation no 

thicker than 0.5 m were sampled at the north of the homonymous ridge (Fig. 1).  

Additionally, two sections from the upper Lagoa do Jacaré Formation were sampled 

and described. The LJ (Lagoa do Jacaré) section crops out along the BR-135 road (km 662 – 

Fig. 1). Dark carbonate layers (1-4 m thick) with oolites, heterolitic lamination and cross 

stratification (Fig. 5f) occur interbedded with light brown siltite and sandstone (Fig. 4). The 

FAS (Fazenda Água Santa) section consists of a tilted 23 m block of dark carbonate with light 

brown siltite at the base and top. Mudstone intraclasts are commonly found within the 

carbonate matrix.

3. Materials and Methods 

 

A total of 331 carbonate rock samples from twelve stratigraphic sections (Fig. 4) were 

described and analysed in this study. Samples were collected with a 1 m vertical resolution, 

exception made to sections SJL and FN where samples were retrieved within 10 cm and 50 

cm interval, respectively.  All isotope analyses were carried out at the Geochronological 

Research Center (CPGeo) of the University of São Paulo. Carbonate powders were obtained 

by microdrilling homogeneous areas of fresh samples devoid of fractures, veins, and mineral 

filling. 

Carbon and oxygen analysis were performed by reacting sample powders with 100% 

H3PO4, under a He atmosphere. The C and O isotopic composition of the CO2 extracted was 

then measured in a Delta Advantage mass spectrometer. The results are reported in the ? 

notation, relative to PDB standard. Instrumental precision was ± 0.05‰ for ?
13

C and ±0.07‰ 

for ?
18

O. Strontium isotopic compositions were obtained using a two-step leaching technique. 

First leaching was performed by reacting ~100 mg of sample powders with HCl 0.1 N 

solution for one hour. Samples were centrifuged and washed three times with Milli Q water. 

These first leachates were then discarded. After drying, the residues underwent a second 

reaction with HCl 1 N solution for 30 minutes, with the amount of acid adjusted to leach 70% 

of the remaining sample mass. The samples were again centrifuged and washed three times 

with Milli Q water.  These second leachates were separated from the residue and purified by 

ion exchange chromatography technique. Their 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios were measured on a TIMS 

Triton mass spectrometer. Corrections for mass fractionation were based on 
87

Sr/
86

Sr = 

0.1194, and the average value of the NBS-987 standard measured during analyses was 

0.710237± 0.000027. Blanks were no higher than 150 pg. 

Trace and major contents were determined by melting 0.2 g of whole rock samples 

with lithium metaborate/tetraborate, followed by diluted nitric acid attack and ICP-OES 

(major elements) and ICP-MS (trace elements) analysis at Acme and ALS Global 

laboratories.

CI-1 and CI-2 samples clearly display higher Si and Al contents than CI-3 which 

corroborates the higher siliciclastic content observed in petrography. Si contents range from 

2.16 to 9.96% in CI-1 and between 2.88 and 10.27% in CI-2 whereas the concentrations of 

such element are no higher than 2.40% in CI-3. Al contents in the CI-1 range from 0.56 to 

1.51%, from 0.61 to 2.60% in CI-2 and are lower than 0.35% in CI-3. The sample from the 

Serra the Santa Helena Formation (SH-02) provided Si and Al concentrations of 1.76 and 

0.30%, respectively. The Lagoa do Jacaré Formation sample yielded Si values between 0.96 

and 15.52% and Al contents between 0.16 and 3.67% with the higher values being found in 

the LJ section where oolites with quartz and feldspars in nucleae can be observed.  

Samples exhibit decreasing upwards Mg content in Sete Lagoas Formation coupled to 

a Ca increasing trend, showing more calcitic limestones to the top. This drop down in the 

Mg/Ca ratios is linked to a decrease in the detrital content of the samples. CI-1 carbonate 

rocks display Mg content between 0.76 and 6.75% and Ca contents between 22.11 and 37% 

(Mg/Ca ratios between 0.02-0.31); Mg contents in CI-2 samples range within 0.48 to 4.64% 

and Ca contents in the 24.44 - 36.45% interval (Mg/Ca = 0.02-0.16); the Mg contents for the 

CI-3 range from 0.08 to 0.33% and the Ca contents from 37.21 to 42.03% (Mg/Ca<0.02). 

The Serra de Santa Helena sample has 0.28 and 38.81% of Mg and Ca content, respectively 

(Mg/Ca ~ 0.01). Samples from Lagoa do Jacaré Formation have Mg contents ranging between 

0.20-4.60% and Ca contents ranging from 21.73 to 38.02% (Mg/Ca = 0.01-0.14). Carbonate 

rocks from the FAS section have higher Mg concentrations than the LJ section. 

Mn and Fe contents also display a decreasing upward trend. CI-1 samples yielded values 

between 0.02-0.16% and 0.31-1.03% for Mn and Fe, respectively. CI-2 carbonates have 

concentrations for both elements between 0.03-0.10% and 0.28-1.06%, respectively. 

However, most of the Mn values obtained for this interval range from 0.02 to 0.03%. The 

upper CI-3 display Mn values lower than 0.03% and Fe values lower than 0.20%. Sample SH-

02 has Mn and Fe contents of 0.02% and 0.27%, respectively. Carbonate rocks of Lagoa do 

Jacaré Formation have Mn contents similar to the CI-3 interval (<0.07%) and Fe contents 

between 0.15 – 1.50%. 

The most striking feature of the whole rock geochemistry results is the strong variation 

observed on Sr concentrations between the two basal intervals and the topmost one. CI-1 and 

CI-2 Sr contents are always lower than 655 ppm, with the basal interval yielding the lowest 

values (usually <300 ppm). In contrast, CI-3 carbonate rocks are highly enriched in Sr with 

contents as high as 4487 ppm with most of the samples showing concentrations above 2000 

ppm. Rb contents are higher than 10 ppm at the lowermost chemostratigraphic intervals and 



90 

 

usually lower than 10 ppm in CI-3, although there are some exceptions. From that comes the 

fact that the lower intervals have Rb/Sr > 0.02, Mn/Sr > 0.5, Fe/Sr > 5 and Ca/Sr ratios > 540, 

whereas CI-3 rocks have Rb/Sr <0.01, Mn/Sr <0.15, Fe/Sr <1.10 and Ca/Sr ratios <410. 

Sample SH-02 has Sr and Rb contents of 2010 ppm and 5 ppm, respectively. Lagoa do Jacaré 

samples have Sr and Rb contents between 800-2210 ppm and 2-47 ppm, respectively. 

Regarding the geochemical ratios related to Sr, these units are closer to the CI-3 than to the 

lowermost intervals of the Sete Lagoas Formation (Table 1).

5. Discussions 

 

5.1. Assessment of post-depositional alterations  

 

The evaluation of our isotope data regarding their meaning as a primary record of 

seawater is crucial for isotope chemostratigraphy, especially when dealing with ancient 

carbonate rocks that may have undergone several episodes of fluid interaction (Melezhik et 

al., 2001). Such process leads to a decrease of carbonate ?
13

C and ?
18

O values as well as to 

more radiogenic 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios (Veizer et al., 1983; Banner and Hanson, 1990; Melezhik et 

al., 2001; Halverson et al., 2007; Derry, 2010). Therefore, identifying post-depositional 

alteration of the isotope record is a fundamental issue, especially for Sr, which is a trace 

element in carbonates and for that reason more susceptible to change in its isotopic 

composition. 

The evaluation of post-depositional alteration is usually performed by analysing the 

geochemical content of carbonate samples. During post-depositional rock/fluid interaction Ca 

and Sr are removed from the carbonate lattice and replaced by Mn and Fe (Veizer et al., 1983; 

Banner and Hanson, 1990). For this reason, Mn/Sr and Fe/Sr geochemical ratios as well as 

Sr/Ca vs. Mn diagrams can be used to monitor alteration. Moreover, several studies attempted 

to define cut off values for these ratios in order to determine the reliability of a given isotope 

dataset. However, such studies used a limited range of samples, usually from a single 

geological unit or from units that share similar histories. This means that these cut offs may 

not be suitable for every ancient carbonate succession. Here we will use our own geochemical 

database to define the best post-depositional screening ratios for them. Another evaluation 

proposal was made by Halverson et al. (2007), which used a diagram method to analyse the 



100 

 

ratios. Using 
87

Sr/
86

Sr vs. Sr plots they established a cut off of 300 ppm for Sr as the limit for 

considering an isotope ratio as non-alterated. We also apply this evaluation procedure here, 

but again without taking the 300 ppm cut off. This is an important procedure for the São 

Francisco Basin as its epicontinental setting may result in significant geochemical differences 

when compared to continental margins carbonate successions. 

Another issue to be addressed is the specific assessment of post-depositional 

alterations of the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios at each chemostratigraphic interval. Previous works show 

significant variations in the C isotope record of the Sete Lagoas Formation, meaning that 

major changes in environmental conditions during deposition occurred (Santos et al., 2000; 

Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al., 2007). Such changes may have led not only to great 

variations in the isotope pool but also in the elementary chemistry of the environment. For 

instance, the transition from lower to upper Sete Lagoas Formation, which coincides with our 

CI-2 to CI-3 transition, is characterized by a significant increase in Sr concentrations of the 

carbonate rocks from ca. 500 ppm to higher than 1500 ppm (Alvarenga et al., 2007, 2014; 

Paula-Santos et al., 2015; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). The fact that this transition is also 

marked by a sharp increase in the ?
13

C values from around +2 to more than +6 ‰ (Santos et 

al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al., 2007) provides significant evidence for 

major differences in seawater chemistry. Using the post depositional alteration screening 

method proposed by Halverson et al. (2007) or even cut off ratios based on the Sr content of 

the samples could lead to discard 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from CI-2 based on the lower Sr 

concentrations of the samples that could have resulted from changes in the São Francisco 

Basin seawater composition rather than from a post depositional cause. In order to avoid such 

misleading, we propose a different approach on such matter by screening for post-

depositional modifications of the isotope record of each CI separately.

87

87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios between 0.7080 and 0.7087 for the interval 

CI-2 are also reported by Kuchenbecker et al. (2016) and Alvarenga et al. (2014). In these 

works, such ratios have been ruled out after comparison against the CI-3 Sr enriched 

carbonates. Our geochemical data evaluation approach suggests that at least the less 

radiogenic Sr isotope ratios from this interval of values are representative of seawater. The 

ratios of the CI-2 more radiogenic than 0.7090 found in sections located closer to the São 

Francisco Basin eastern margin (sections LV and FN) or on basement highs (section IN) 

should also be discarded as they show significant rock/fluid interaction as observed in the  Sr, 

Mn and Fe relationships (Fig. 7). Such regions were probably more susceptible to freshwater 

supply during early diagenesis making it more difficult to preserve seawater Sr isotope 

composition. This hypothesis is supported by the higher detrital content admixed in the 

carbonate matrix of sections FN, LV and IN (used here as proxy for paleodepositional 

freshwater input monitoring) when compared to section SC, positive correlations between 

87
Sr/

86
Sr vs. [Si] and 

87
Sr/

86
Sr vs. Al (R

2
 ~0.4 for both relationships), and by the lighter ?

18
O 

composition on the sections FN, LV and IN. These are evidence for stronger freshwater 

influence on these sites regarding the paleodepositional environment. Alternatively, the 

isotopic compositions of sections FN and LV could have been modified by hydrothermalism 

during deformational processes, as suggested by the extensive display of tectonic structures.

paleodepositional freshwater input. However other coastal freshwater sources such as 

groundwater discharge could also provide more radiogenic isotopic ratios (Beck et al., 2013) 

without a detrital input. Any of the proposed options for explaining the large variation of

al., 2016).

5.2. The Sr isotope record and the evolution of the São Francisco Basin 

 

The 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios obtained here and considered to be primary, as well as previous 

data reevaluated, reveal a dynamic evolution of the Sr isotope composition of the São 

Francisco Basin seawater, coeval with the C isotope evolution of the basin, which is 

summarized in Fig. 10.  

Although our data for the CI-1 may not be conclusive, Babinski et al. (2007) presented 

more detailed Sr isotope profiles for the basal cap carbonates of the Sete Lagoas Formation on 

Sambra and Tatiana quarries located on the southern border of the São Francisco Basin. 

Those authors reported an increase in 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from 0.7074 to 0.7081 in 10 m of 

carbonate succession on Sambra quarry and from 0.7079 to 0.7082 in 3 m on Tatiana Quarry. 

This increase in the Sr isotopic composition is coeval with the recovery of ?
13

C values from 

very negative values (-4.5 ‰) to values around 0‰ at the beginning of CI-2. In this scenario, 

the increase in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios could be interpreted as a result of enhanced chemical 

weathering of silicates after the younger Cryogenian glacial period. Halverson et al. (2010) 

and Kuznetsov et al. (2013) recognized a peak in the Sr isotope composition of the oceans in 

the aftermath of such glaciation with 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios reaching as high as 0.7080 before a 

recovery to values around 0.7075 interpreted as the expected outcome of a sharp increase in 

pCO2 on the post-glacial atmosphere. We note, however, that the cap carbonate CI-1 shows a 

positive ?
44

Ca excursion reported by Silva-Tamayo et al. (2010a) on the Sambra section.

but starting with a significant contribution of carbonate weathering and then transitioning into 

a silicate dominated weathering regime (Silva-Tamayo et al., 2010b; Kasemann et al., 2014). 

The negative excursion in the ?
13

C values from -3 to -5‰ (before recovering to values around 

0‰) found on the basal cap dolostones from CI-1 (Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et al., 2007; 

Caxito et al., 2012; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016) has been considered as a distinctive feature of 

post Marinoan cap carbonates differentiating them from post Sturtian ones (Hoffman et al., 

2004; Knoll et al., 2004; Condon et al., 2005). Caxito et al. (2012) and Alvarenga et al. (2014) 



106 

 

considered the glacial deposits at the base of the Bambuí Group as a Marinoan record in the 

São Francisco Basin, based on C and Sr data reported above. 

However, our interpretation of the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios brings new evidence about the 

isotope record of the basal part of the Bambuí Group. The increase in the Sr isotopic ratios 

observed in CI-1 stabilizes around 0.7082 and persists for most of the CI-2 for which detrital 

zircons and the occurrence of Cloudina sp. provide late Ediacaran ages. So there is no 

conclusive peak in Sr ratios in the aftermath of cap carbonate deposition. The stable 
87

Sr/
86

Sr 

ratios around 0.7082 at CI-2 are typical of the late Ediacaran (Melezhik et al., 2001; 

Halverson et al., 2007, 2010; Kuznetsov et al., 2013). Analyzing the whole picture, this 

increase in 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios and ?
13

C values that characterizes the CI-1 may simply be an effect 

of marine transgression, causing a transition from a shallow environment influenced by local 

conditions to a stage that would be connected to the global pool (Fig. 10).  

Another issue about the CI-1, is the age of the diamictites positioned below it. Our 

interpretation of the Sr evolution of the basal cap carbonates is not consistent with the one 

reported for post Marinoan successions. The gradual isotopic and lithologic (verified in our 

section IN and by Kuchenbecker et al., 2016) transition to the Late Ediacaran Cloudina sp. 

bearing CI-2 most likely place the glacial record of the São Francisco Basin and its overlying 

cap carbonates on the Late Ediacaran, as recently proposed by Kuchenbecker et al. (2016). No 

field evidence support major sedimentation gaps between CI-1 and CI-2 that would be ca. 80 

My if a Marinoan age is assumed (Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2014) or ca. 200 My if 

a Sturtian age is claimed (Babinski et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007). Additionally, the lack of 

secular variations in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios throughout the CI-2 does not support equally long 

sedimentation periods. Other Late Ediacaran glaciations (post-Gaskiers) have been reported 

worldwide (e.g. Deynoux et al., 2006; Hebert et al., 2010; Etemad-Saeed et al., in press). 

Carbonate rocks atop such deposits are scarce, but the few C isotope data available also show 

a negative ?
13

C excursion (e.g. Etemad-Saeed et al., 2015), which may be equivalent to the 

CI-1. 



107 

 

 

Fig. 10 – Chemostratigraphic subdivision proposal for the lower three units of the Bambuí Group. Units? thicknesses are not to scale. The ages presented are: 

(a) Pb-Pb isochron age (Babinski et al., 2007); (b) constrained by presence of Cloudina sp. (Warren et al., 2014); (c) U-Pb age of the youngest representative 

detrital zircon population (Paula-Santos et al., 2015).  



108 

 

The Late Ediacaran age for the glacial deposits below the Bambuí Group also requires 

some refinements. The Bambuí Group was deposited in a foreland basin developed in 

response to the crustal overload of the Brasília belt on the west of the São Francisco Craton 

(Martins-Neto et al., 2001; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). Collisional ages span from 630 

Ma at the metamorphic peak of the belt to ca. 540 Ma during post tectonic magmatism 

(Pimentel, 2016). If the subsidence starts at 630 Ma, at least 80 Ma of deposition would occur 

before the CI-2 (maximum age of 550 Ma considering the Cloudina sp occurrence, Grotzinger 

et al., 2000). Kuchenbecker (2014) hypothesized that the orogenic fronts may have eroded 

such record, but further studies still have to be conducted to check this missing part of the 

puzzle.  

Although our isotope data and the lack of field evidence make it hard to assume an 

unconformity between CI-1 and CI-2, we stress that the only radiometric age obtained so far 

for the cap carbonates is a Pb-Pb isochron age of 740 ± 22 Ma (Babinski et al., 2007). 

Moreover, the underlying diamictites lack detrital zircons with Late Cryogenian or Ediacaran 

U-Pb ages (Babinski et al., 2012), that would be expected in Marinoan or Ediacaran times. 

Therefore, such unconformity cannot still be entirely ruled out, and if does exist the 

geochronological data suggest that the glaciation is most likely Sturtian. Although it would be 

incompatible with our evolution model for the CI-1, it would not deny the conception of the 

subdivision only as a tool of isotopic characterization and correlation of the carbonate rocks 

across the São Francisco Basin. Finally, there is some debate about relationships between the 

Carrancas and the Jequitaí formations as well as the glacial origin of the first unit (Vieira et 

al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Uhlein et al., 2012, 2016). Proposals that the Carrancas deposits 

represent pre-glacial records (Uhlein et al., 2016) and that Carrancas and the Jequitaí 

formations represent two distinct glacial periods with possible two cap carbonates 

(Kuchenbecker et al., 2016) are still ongoing.    

The CI-1 positive excursions of ?
13

C, ?
44

Ca and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr stabilize at the CI-2 

boundary. The primary 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios for the second chemostratigraphic interval range 

between 0.7080-0.7085. When compared to several reference curves for the Sr isotope 

evolution of the Neoproterozoic and Cambrian global ocean (e.g. Jacobsen and Kaufman, 

1999; Halverson et al., 2010; Kuznetsov et al., 2013) these ratios match the ones expected for 

the Late Ediacaran and also the depositional age interval for Cloudina sp. (550-542 Ma; 

Grotzinger et al., 2000) that is present in CI-2 (Warren et al., 2014). This index fossil is strong 

evidence that the São Francisco Basin was connected to other Gondwana marine basins 

through a sea pathway (Warren et al., 2014), which in turn allowed isotope homogenization 



109 

 

with the Sr global pool by exchange with external seawaters. Therefore, the CI-2 records a 

connected marine stage of the basin in which seawater mixing, isotope homogenization and 

fossil migration to inner parts of the São Francisco Craton were possible as a sea pathway was 

established linking several Gondwana intracratonic basins. The seaway connections were 

established by a major transgression that flooded the West Gondwana. In the São Francisco 

basin, such sea level rise is recorded in the sedimentary transition from the Carrancas 

Formation to the lower Sete Lagoas Formation (Vieira et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Uhlein 

et al., 2012; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016; this work) and possibly on the rapid isotope positive 

excursion followed by stabilization in normal marine values for the end of the Ediacaran. 

Indeed, the ?
13

C values around 0‰ and the ?
18

O values around -7‰ of the best preserved 

carbonate sections of CI-2 in deeper environments (Alvarenga et al., 2014; SC section of this 

work) also matches normal marine values for the Neoproterozoic (Kah, 2000; Kah et al., 

2012).  

A broad overview of the São Francisco Craton geotectonic framework at the end of the 

Ediacaran period is required for an attempt to reconstruct such connections. The timing of 

oceanic crust consumption and continental collision in the cratonic margins are well 

constrained in the literature. At around 560 Ma, the orogenic belts surrounding the craton 

were already build up (Fig. 1): the Brasília Belt in the west (Pimentel et al., 1999; Pimentel, 

2016), the Araçuaí Belt in the east (Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011b), the Sergipana (Bueno et al., 

2009; Oliveira et al., 2010), Riacho do Pontal (Caxito et al., 2014a) and Rio Preto (Caxito et 

al., 2014b) belts in the north. The Ribeira Belt was also developed to the south of the craton 

(Tupinambá et al., 2000; Heilbron et al., 2008; Meira et al., 2015). Therefore, the São 

Francisco Basin was located in the very core of the West Gondwana continent at the 

Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary (Alkmim et al., 2006; Figs. 1 and 11) and most likely did not 

face the open global ocean. The isotopic homogenization and fauna migration might have 

happened via connection with other marine basins, which in turn could be linked to the ocean. 

The occurrences of Cloudina sp. reported so far are restricted to north part of the São 

Francisco basin, making it most likely that sea pathway connected it to the South Paraguay 

Belt marine basin through the northwest (Meira et al.; 2015; Fig. 11), where occurrences of 

the fossil and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7085 are also reported (Boggiani, 1998). The tectonic 

framework connecting these different marine basins still has to be further investigated, but it 

is highly unlikely that the same species (Cloudina sp.) had appeared at the same time in 

several disconnected environments. Furthermore, seawater exchange through narrow passages 



110 

 

(e.g. the actual Mediterranean connection to the Atlantic Ocean) is enough to promote isotope 

homogenization in inland seas (Kuznetsov et al., 2012).  

 

Fig. 11 – Geological sketch of West Gondwana at ca. 550-542 Ma showing a possible scenario of

the metazoan Cloudina sp. that could have reached the basin through a sea corridor at the north, 

linking it with the South Paraguay Belt basin and providing seawater exchange for isotope 

homogenization. 

 

The transition from the CI-2 to CI-3 is marked by an abrupt shift in ?
13

C values from 

around +2‰ to +8‰ that occurs all over the basin (Santos et al., 2000). In our Sr isotope data 

evaluation, we find that these changes in the C isotope composition is concomitant to a steep 

decrease  in 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from values higher than 0.7080 to values around 0.7075. When 

compared to Sr isotope reference curves (Jacobsen and Kaufman, 1999; Halverson et al., 

2010; Kuznetsov et al., 2013) these lower ratios mismatch those expected for the Late 

Ediacaran and the Early Cambrian. The maximum depositional age of 560 Ma obtained for 

the CI-3 (Paula-Santos et al., 2015) as well as to the Cloudina sp. occurrence at the lower CI-

2 (Warren et al., 2014) confirm that the CI-3 was deposited sometime around the Ediacaran-

Cambrian transition. The discrepant Sr ratios can best be explained by a lack of isotope 

homogenization between the São Francisco Basin and the external seawater, implying a 

completely restriction of the basin (e.g. Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Paula-

Santos et al., 2015). Therefore, the transition from CI-2 to CI-3 records the end of the 

connection of the São Francisco epeiric sea with the Gondwana sea pathway. The 
87

Sr/
86

Sr 



111 

 

ratios and the ?
13

C values from Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations are 

quite close to those of the upper Sete Lagoas Formation and thus these units likely record the 

restricted stage and can be grouped into the CI-3. The sedimentary successions of these three 

units exhibit monotonous sedimentary structures (e.g. massive structure and plane parallel 

lamination), darker color and suspected organic matter preservation (Iyer et al., 1995) as well 

as lack of any guide fossil. The restricted environment may have led to inefficient 

thermohaline circulation, stratified and anoxic seawater causing preservation and burial of 

organic matter (Santos et al., 2000; Vieira et al., 2007; Martins and Lemos, 2007). Inefficient 

circulation can also be a possible explanation for the oscillating 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios found on the 

eastern margin of the basin (section HV). Doebert et al. (2014) showed on the lacustrine 

Eocene Green River Formation that periods of basin restriction may result in higher Sr 

concentrations on authigenic sediments due to evaporation, lower Sr residence time and 

87
Sr/

86
Sr ratios gradient across the basin due to freshwater inputs on its margins. Carbonates 

from CI-3 do display higher Sr concentrations (Table 1) and the ?
18

O values of deeper section 

with less freshwater input (sections CB and MT) show slightly heavier O isotope 

compositions than lower section in the same deeper environments (section CB), suggesting 

higher evaporation conditions which could support a similar model for the Bambuí Group.  

Based on the detrital zircon ages available for the Sete Lagoas Formation, the most probable 

cause of such basin restriction is the uplift of the marginal orogens of the São Francisco 

Craton. The lower CI-2 displays a wider range of sources from Archean to Tonian (Paula-

Santos et al., 2015). The CI-3 exhibits a completely different detrital zircon distribution with 

dominance of few Ediacaran sources, resembling a foreland distribution histogram for 

geochronological samples collected in both western and eastern margins of the basin 

(Pimentel et al., 2011; Paula-Santos et al., 2015). This source changing is a strong evidence 

for uplifting of the marginal orogens during the late Ediacaran and early Cambrian.  

The existence of high relief adjacent to the marine basin is also a possible explanation 

for the lower 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios of the CI-3. The change of the seawater Sr isotope composition 

to less radiogenic 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios could be due to (i) high hydrothermal input, (ii) enhanced 

weathering of juvenile basalts or (iii) of ancient carbonate platforms (Palmer and Edmond, 

1989; Krabenhoft et al., 2010). The first option is the least probable as the continental 

restricted setting suggest that the basin lacks any kind of the hydrothermal activity. The high 

relief model on the margins here assumed would definitely put the third option ahead of the 

second. According to Palmer and Edmond (1992), weathering of carbonate rocks is enhanced 

on highland steepened relief areas because the low residence time of river waters favors 



112 

 

leaching of carbonate minerals rather than silicates. Rivers draining such areas are usually 

enriched in Sr and have lower 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios. Blum et al. (1998) showed that up to 82% of Sr 

of freshwater in the Himalayans highland areas derives from weathering of carbonate rocks, 

even if they represent only 1% of the source rocks. This process is reversed in the flat lowland 

areas where the longer reaction time between water and minerals enhances silicate 

weathering. If similar processes occurred in the São Francisco Basin, during deposition of 

upper Sete Lagoas (CI-3), Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations, the epeiric 

sea coastlines must have reached the bottom of mountain ranges, thus flooding the lowland 

areas and collecting Sr enriched freshwater with low 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios. Such scenario probably 

started in the CI-2 to CI-3 transition and along with restriction led to deposition of Sr enriched 

carbonates with 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7075. Ancient Paleoproterozoic and 

Mesoproterozoic carbonate units with low 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios were available in the craton area 

and marginal orogens (e.g. Paleoproterozoic Gandarela and Fecho do Funil Formations; 

Mesoproterozoic Rio Pardo and Paranoá formations). Uplifting of São Francisco Craton 

surrounding belts during the Ediacaran-Cambrian transition is predicted for the Araçuaí 

(Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2008, 2011),  Sergipana (Bueno et al., 2009; Oliveira et al., 2010), 

Riacho do Pontal (Caxito et al., 2014a) and Rio Preto (Caxito et al., 2014b) belts. The 

evolution of the western Brasília Belt is not completely in disagreement with this, but the 

magmatism therein dated around 540 Ma were obtained in post orogenic rocks. As the major 

change in the Sr composition recorded in Sete Lagoas Formation requires a combined change 

in Sr budget of freshwaters from all the source areas and the former basin connection to the 

global pool may have existed in the west during the CI-2 stage, perhaps some minor 

refinements in the timing of uplift and restriction is required either by new information about 

the basin or the Brasilia belt. Influence of intracontinental deformation (Meira et al., 2015) or 

of a possible closure of an Ediacaran ocean to the west of the craton (Trindade et al., 2006; 

Tohver et al., 2010; McGee et al., 2015) in the uplift events cannot be ruled out. These issues 

are key for the full understanding of the assembly of the West Gondwana.     

To summarize our proposal, CI-1 and CI-2 record the beginning of transgression and 

connection of the São Francisco Basin to a Gondwana sea pathway, providing biota migration 

and isotope homogenization. The transition of CI-2 to CI-3 marks the demise of such 

connection and the onset of a restricted epeiric sea, keeping the basin apart from the global 

ocean isotope pool. 

 

5.3. Interpretation of the C isotope record 



113 

 

 

The carbon isotope chemostratigraphy is crucial on studies regarding the sequences of 

the Bambuí Group. In spite of the idea of a simple stratigraphy, the long extension of the São 

Francisco Basin and its great lateral sedimentary facies variations make correlation by 

conventional techniques a non trivial task. As discussed previously, ?
13

C obtained on 

carbonates provide the most reliable tool for basinal correlation as characteristic fluctuations 

with regional extension distinguish three different chemostratigraphic intervals on the Sete 

Lagoas Formation (Santos et al., 2000, 2004; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al; 2007). 

Our Sr isotope discussion showed that the upper CI-3 also groups the Serra de Santa Helena 

and the Lagoa do Jacaré formations, which reinforces the usefulness of such technique. 

Moreover, this work demonstrates that such fluctuations in the C isotope record are coupled 

to variations in the Sr isotope composition on the unit providing a chance for a further step 

onto the interpretation of the ?
13

C values.        

The negative excursion in the ?
13

C values from -3 to -5‰ followed by the recovery to 

values around 0‰ that marks the CI-1 has been interpreted in the context of the 

Neoproterozoic glaciations. This CI is composed by dolostones, with aragonites 

pseudomorphes considered as cap carbonates deposited in the aftermath of a glacial event, 

assumed as Sturtian (Vieira et al., 2007; Babinski et al., 2007; Silva-Tamayo et al., 2010) or 

Marinoan (Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et al., 2014). In such context, this positive excursion 

is interpreted as a recovery from a scenario of post-glacial greenhouse condition with high 

pCO2 to a more stable climatic condition driven by high rates of CO2 consumption via 

enhanced chemical weathering (Vieira et al., 2007; Silva-Tamayo et al., 2010). Although a 

more detailed investigation across the negative C excursion should still be conducted, the 

analysis of the Sr isotope composition variations do not seem to support this hypothesis but 

rather suggest a change from a shallow restrict setting to a connected basin in response to 

marine transgression. The 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from CI-1 rapidly increase from 0.7074 to 0.7082 

which persist throughout the CI-2 during the connected phase. The C isotope positive 

excursion also stabilizes on values around 0‰ which characterize most of the CI-2, 

resembling a similar evolution as the Sr isotopes and thus providing background for such 

interpretation. In this framework, the very negative ?
13

C values could be the result of the input 

of continental carbon in shallow restricted marine environments, with progressive increase in 

the values as transgression takes place until achieving full connection between the São 

Francisco Basin and the Gondwana sea pathway. At this stage, the influence of continental 



114 

 

carbon is suppressed by isotopic homogenization with external seawaters. This hypothesis is 

usually not accepted for the Neoproterozoic as organisms capable of fractionating C 

presumably did not exist on the continents. However, Knauth and Kennedy (2009) discussed 

such possibility arguing that the ?
13

C values commonly found on cap carbonates are similar to 

those described in the Phanerozoic, so that we find valid at least discussing it. Finally, as 

discussed earlier, a possible unconformity between CI-1 and CI-2, the origin of the Carrancas 

Formation (Vieira et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; Ulhein et al., 2012, 2016) and the existence 

of two different diamictite units (Jequitaí and Carrancas formations; Kuchenbecker et al., 

2016) each one with its respective cap carbonate, are crucial for future interpretations of the C 

isotope meaning of the CI-1 record. 

Despite the doubts on the meaning of the very negative ?
13

C values for the CI-1, fossil 

records and Sr isotope data converge towards a clear interpretation for the C record of the CI-

2. The presence of Cloudina sp. index fossil and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios between 0.7080-0.7085 argue 

in favour of a sea pathway connecting several marine basins throughout the West Gondwana 

(Warren et al., 2014), including the São Francisco Basin. The??
13

C values for the CI-2 around 

0‰ match this scenario as they are close to the PDB standard value and also to normal marine 

values for the Neoproterozoic (Kah, 2000; Kah et al., 2012), meaning that the basin may have 

achieved a steady state regarding C fractionation. The ??
18

O values around -7‰ obtained on 

deep environment settings for this stage (Alvarenga et al., 2014; section SC of this work) are 

also close to open marine values for this Era. 

The transition from CI-2 to CI-3 is marked by the abrupt shift on the ??
13

C profile to 

extremely high values up to 16‰. Despite being of basinal extension (Santos et al., 2000), 

this transition occurs in different ways along the São Francisco basin. In the northeast and 

north portions of the basin, the top of the CI-2 displays a long positive excursion reaching 

??
13

C values of 5‰ (Martins and Lemos, 2007). In the southern sector, sections exhibit a 

much more abrupt shift, with a steep inflection starting at values around 2‰ (Vieira et al., 

2007; section SC in this work – Fig. 3). Therefore, such transition may be a diachronic 

regional unconformity also marked by a lithological contrast. Whereas the CI-1 and CI-2 are 

dominantly composed by carbonate rocks throughout the whole basin, the upper CI-3 shows a 

lateral facies variation of pelitic siliciclastic rocks and dark carbonates with relatively 

monotonous sedimentary structures, with the siliciclastic lithotypes being more dominant 

westwards (Martins and Lemos, 2007). Such lateral variation would control the distribution of 

the upper Sete Lagoas, Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations. In this way, 



115 

 

we find that our CI-3 matches the sequence 3 of Martins and Lemos (2007), composed by the 

units deposited in a stacked ramp environment model with restricted circulation and stratified 

water column, which created conditions to the higher ??
13

C values. As shown by the decrease 

in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios presented in this work and by the source changing demonstrated by U-

Pb ages in detrital zircons (Paula-Santos et al., 2015) from CI-2 to CI-3, such restriction was 

probably caused by tectonic uplifiting in the São Francisco Craton margins that ended the 

connection of its epicontinental sea to the Gondwana sea pathway. 

The most accepted hypothesis for the high ??
13

C values on the CI-3 is preservation and 

burial of organic matter (Iyer et al., 1995; Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; 

Vieira et al., 2007), although TOC (total organic carbon) and ??
13

Corg data necessary for such 

evaluation are scarce. The only systematic study in such way was performed by Iyer et al. 

(1995). Their data support such hypothesis as the ??
13

Ccarb positive excursion is coupled to a 

?
13

Corg positive excursion, which would indicate that progressively enrichment in 
13

C of the 

dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) of seawater was a consequence of 
12

C burial (Kump and 

Arthur, 1999). Even though the measured TOC are low (0.1-0.7%, Iyer et al., 1995), it must 

be considered that the CI-3 is composed of black carbonates with oil stains (Fig. 5e) and the 

organic constituents may have been degraded and depleted during the thermal evolution of the 

basin. Nevertheless, the mean and median values calculated for the carbon isotopic 

fractionation (?
13

C= ?
13

Ccarb - ?
13

CTOC, Hayes et al., 1999) with data from Iyer et al. (1995) 

are 27.0 and 26.2‰, respectively, for the CI-2 and 28.2 and 28.7‰, respectively for the CI-3. 

Such difference between the intervals is too low so that both C excursions in the carbonate 

and organic fractions are coupled and fit one of the scenarios modelled by Kump and Arthur 

(1999) for organic matter burial and constant carbon fractionation. In fact, using a simple 

steady-state model, we can estimate the fraction of buried organic carbon ?org = (?
13

Cinput + 

?
13

Ccarb) / (?
13

CTOC + ?
13

Ccarb) (Hayes et al., 1999), assuming ?
13

Cinput = -5‰ (global average; 

e.g. Hoefs, 2009) and provided ?
13

Ccarb and ?
13

Corg are available for the same sample. Using 

the data of Iyer et al. (1995), mean values of ?org are 24.7‰ for the CI-2 and 65.6‰ for the 

CI-3. These numbers would imply an anomalous increase of organic matter burial rates from 

CI-2 to CI-3. Restriction and stratified water columns are usually argued for carbon 

preservation and 
13

C enrichment in carbonates of the Bambuí Group (Iyer et al., 1995; Santos 

et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al., 2007). Our epicontinental restricted basin 

framework based on Sr isotopes for the CI-3 agrees with that. 



116 

 

However, recent modelling conducted by Birgel et al. (2015) showed that ?
13

C values 

higher than 10‰, such as those obtained for the upper Sete Lagoas Formation (e.g. Iyer et al., 

1995; Vieira et al., 2007) and for the Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations 

(this work), cannot be achieved only by means of organic matter burial. The authors propose 

that an additional C fractionating process should also take place, such as the degradation of 

the organic matter by archea activity through methanogenesis in anoxic environments. Such 

process occurs by fermentation of acetate which produces methane depleted in 
13

C and 
13

C 

enriched CO2 (Whiticar et al., 1986). If the CH4 is readily lost to the atmosphere, the CO2 can 

become part of DIC of pore waters, thus leading to precipitation of carbonates with extremely 

heavy C isotope compositions (Meister et al., 2011; Birgel et al., 2015). Based on studies on 

modern stromatolites with ?
13

C values as high as 16‰ in the Salgada Lagoon (SE Brazil), 

Birgel et al. (2015) assume that two conditions are necessary for methanogenesis to take place 

and influence the ?
13

C record of carbonates precipitated: (i) high salinity, leading to CH4 loss 

by decreasing solubility and, thus, avoiding its oxidation, and (ii) low sulphate supply, 

inhibiting sulphate reducers metabolism. Hipersalinity conditions are not known for the 

Bambuí Group, although ?
18

O values in sections with less freshwater influence from CI-3 

(sections CB and MT) are slightly higher than in CI-2 (section SC), suggesting higher 

evaporation rates. But the second condition seems to be plausible for the unit. In the case of 

the Salgada Lagoon, Birgel et al. (2015) identify that the low sulphate supply occurs during 

periods when the lagoon is devoid of connection with the Atlantic Ocean, which is the main 

SO4
2-

 source, remaining only with the low [SO4
2-

] reservoir of freshwater. The restricted 

scenario here proposed for the CI-3 stage, when the São Francisco Basin would have no 

connection to other Gondwana epicontinental seas neither to the global ocean, is similar to the 

Salgada Lagoon. The lack of connection to external seawater may have cut the main SO4
2-

 

supply of the basin leading to a steepened draw down in the sulphate reservoir. Combined to 

the preservation of organic matter suggested by coupled ?
13

Ccarb and ?
13

Corg positive isotope 

excursions (Iyer et al., 1995) and consequent anoxic eodiagenetic conditions, an ideal 

environment for archea methanogenesis was set in some portions of the basin. In fact, ?
13

C 

values higher than 10‰ are usually found in shallow facies carbonates such as the 

stromatolites from the upper Sete Lagoas Formation (Iyer et al., 1995; Vieira et al., 2007) and 

the oolitic and intraclastic carbonates from the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation (sections LJ and 

FAS, respectively). So, we suggest that methanogenesis must had been relevant locally in 

shallower settings where restriction and evaporative conditions where higher. To summarize, 

we propose that the unusual high ?
13

C values from CI-3 are result of enhanced organic carbon 



117 

 

preservation, possibly associated with anoxic environments in a restricted and stagnant 

environment, with the extreme values representing methanogenesis and evaporation on 

shallower settings. Our scenario is in agreement with previous works carried out in the 

Bambuí Group (Iyer et al., 1995; Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al., 

2007). 

 

5.4. Implications for isotope chemostratigraphy across West Gondwana 

 

The case of the Bambuí Group clearly shows that the Sr isotope “blind dating” may 

fail without observing the geotectonic setting in which the carbonate succession was 

deposited. A further look into Ediacaran units of the West Gondwana shows that similar 

problems may have happened during the assembly of the continent, when several 

intracontinental settings were created. 

The Arroyo del Soldado Group covers part of the Rio de la Plata Craton in Uruguay 

and comprises a marine platform succession more than 5000 m thick (Gaucher, 2000). The 

unit bares the Cloudina riemkeae (Gaucher, 2000; Gaucher and Poiré, 2009) which combined 

with a maximum depositional age of 566 ± 8 Ma obtained by LA-ICP-MS in the youngest 

detrital zircon of the unit (Gaucher et al., 2008) suggest a Late Ediacaran age at least for the 

three basal formations of the Group (from base to top Yerbal, Polanco and Barriga Negra 

formations), similar to the Bambuí Group. The 
87

Sr/
86

Sr profile of the unit begins with a 

decrease from ratios between 0.7080-0.7086 to ratios as low as 0.7073, marking the end of 

first ?
13

C positive excursion from the unit and the onset of the first negative excursion 

(Gaucher et al., 2009). The low radiogenic Sr ratios occurs in carbonates with high Sr 

contents (up to 2250 ppm), similarly to the Bambuí Group CI-3 carbonates, and spam out 

through 300 m of the stratigraphy of the Polanco Formation reaching a minimum of 0.7067 

(Aubet et al., 2012). These ratios remain low until the beginning of a second ?
13

C positive 

excursion in Polanco Formation, when the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios rise again to values higher than 

0.7080 (Gaucher et al., 2009; Frei et al., 2011). Although the negative Sr excursion could be 

correlated to the one observed in the Bambuí Group, the C isotope profile of the Arroyo del 

Soldado Group in this stratigraphic sector is different as the decrease in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios 

comes together with a C negative excursion, whereas in the Brazilian unit such ratios decrease 

is linked to a pronounced positive excursion in the ?
13

C values. This could mean that such 

excursions are different in age or distinct results of different depositional setting and 



118 

 

environmental conditions. The causes advocated for the lower 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios are different. 

Gaucher et al. (2009) and Frei et al. (2011) claim that they are a result of enhanced 

hydrothermal input into the basins during a time in which some continental areas were 

covered by high latitude glacial sheets, presumably during the non-global Gaskiers glaciation. 

It contrasts with our model of restriction of the São Francisco Basin with enhanced carbonate 

weathering driven by uplifting of surrounding mountain ranges. Aubet et al. (2012) propose a 

stratified water column during the deposition of the Arroyo del Soldado carbonates, which 

could somehow be similar to the Bambuí Group, although this fact alone does not explain the 

less radiogenic Sr isotope values. Nevertheless, in both units the lower 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios are not 

compatible with those predicted for global ocean Sr isotope composition in many presented 

evolution curves (e.g. Jacobson and Kaufman, 1999; Halverson et al., 2010; Kuznetsov et al., 

2013). 

Another example of such mismatch in West Gondwana could be the Sierras Bayas 

Group, Tandilia System, Argentina. The least altered 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios reported for the unit are 

between 0.7069 and 0.7075 in its uppermost Loma Negra Formation (Kawashita et al., 1999). 

Although Goméz Peral et al. (2007) proposed an age between 590-580 Ma based on C and Sr 

blind dating, the presence of the index fossil Cloudina sp. in the unit (Gaucher et al., 2005) 

most likely put the deposition of the Loma Negra Formation closer to the Ediacaran-

Cambrian boundary. In this case the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios would again be lower than the expected 

for the period. 

The cases of the Arroyo del Soldado, Sierras Bayas and Bambuí groups all point 

toward a problem of using Sr isotope geochemistry for global correlations. The causes for the 

lower 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios may differ among each unit, but they all show local strong influences on 

the Sr isotope composition of coeval seawater, as such non radiogenic ratios are not predicted 

in global Sr curves. Ultimately, this discrepancy may have been caused by the onset of several 

epicontinental marine settings during the assembly of the West Gondwana. Such basins were 

subject to different degrees and durations of restriction, sometimes favoring local controls 

over global ones. In a similar way to the South American units, the Duoshantuo Formation in 

the Yangtze platform in south China might have had limited connection to the global ocean 

(Wang and Li, 2003) and present variations in 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios across the shallow and deep 

environments that could be caused by hydrothermal activity inside the basin (Hohl et al., 

2015), rather than global processes. 

These cases illustrate that Sr global correlations and blind dating must be done with 

caution after a careful study of the basin geotectonic frame. Furthermore, such study is crucial 



119 

 

when deciding how to deal with their isotope record as proxy for global events during the 

important life transition across the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary. However, it does not 

invalidate the usefulness of Sr chemostratigraphy for identifying and evaluating significant 

tectonic and climatic changes through Earth?s history.              

       

6. Conclusions      

 

We propose that the three lower units of the Bambuí Group can be grouped into three 

chemostratigraphic intervals based on the C and Sr isotope composition of their carbonates, 

each one recording a different geological stage of the epicontinental São Francisco Basin. Our 

evaluation of the Sr isotope record of the unit shows that the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios co vary with the 

?
13

C values.  

The lower CI-1 corresponds to the basal cap carbonates of the Sete Lagoas Formation 

and marks a change from a shallow restrict setting dominated by freshwater input to a basin 

connected to external seawaters. This scenario is recorded in the initial negative excursion in 

the ?
13

C values from -3 to -5‰, followed by a positive excursion with ?
13

C values increasing 

from -5 to 0‰, which is coeval with a positive excursion in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from 0.7074 to 

0.7082 in less than 10 m of carbonate succession. The CI-2 lithologically matches the middle 

portion of the Sete Lagoas Formation and records the full onset of a connection between the 

São Francisco and other Gondwana marine basins through a continental sea pathway, marked 

by the presence of the index fossil Cloudina sp.. The ?
13

C values around 0‰ and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr 

ratios close to 0.7082, which matches the expected for the Late Ediacaran, resemble this 

framework. After a positive shift in the C record, the CI-3 establishes the demise of such 

connection and the start of restricted epeiric marine basin devoid of efficient mixing with 

external seawaters. This interval groups the upper Sete Lagoas, Serra de Santa Helena and 

Lagoa do Jacaré formations, which carbonates display unusual high ?
13

C values up to +16‰ 

and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7075, considerably less radiogenic than the expected for the 

Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary. The basin restriction was possibly caused by tectonic uplifting 

of orogenic belts at the São Francisco Craton margins, changing the chemical weathering 

regime and favouring carbonate leaching on highland areas that provided high [Sr] and low 

radiogenic 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios. At the same time, restriction led to a stagnant, possibly anoxic, 

stratified and sulphate depleted seawater column providing conditions to carbon preservation 

and organic matter burial, while methanogenesis and evaporation locally played a significant 



120 

 

role in shallower environments. Such paleoenvironmental conditions should be further 

investigated via other proxies.  

The Sr isotope mismatch also occur in other carbonate successions across the West 

Gondwana, suggesting that the amalgamation of the continent may have generated several 

intracontinental marine settings favouring local controls on the Sr budget. As a consequence, 

caution is suggested in the application of Sr blind dating and global correlations of carbonate 

successions using 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios.
