6.2. Elementos Terras Raras 

 

 Os dados de Elementos Terras Raras (ETR) obtidos nas amostras de rochas 

carbonáticas são apresentados e discutidos no artigo científico “Rare earth elements of 

carbonate rocks from the Bambuí Group, southern São Francisco Basin, Brazil, and their 

significance as paleoenvironmental proxies”, submetido ao periódico Precambrian Research. 

 Este trabalho apresenta os primeiros dados de ETR obtidos para o Grupo Bambuí pela 

técnica de lixiviação e análise somente da fração carbonática da amostras. Acompanhando a 

subdivisão feita no item 6.1., as distribuições normalizadas são diferenciadas para cada CI. Os 

calcários do CI-1 apresentam tal distribuição planar, que sugere ampla influência de água 

doce na bacia após o período glacial. Já as amostras do CI-2 apresentaram uma distribuição 

normalizada de tendência planar, porém com algumas características semelhantes ao padrão 

“água do mar” como anomalias positivas de La e Y, sugerindo menor influência continental e 

mistura com bacias marinhas externas durante o estágio de conexão da bacia. Curiosamente, o 

chamado padrão “água do mar” se desenvolve no estágio restrito da bacia (CI-3). Isto pode 

ser explicado pela diminuição do fluxo continental dissolvido para a bacia do São Francisco 

devido ao aumento da taxa de denudação das áreas fontes e consequente decréscimo da 

intensidade de intemperismo. A baixa intensidade de intemperismo provavelmente causou um 

aumento da importância de rochas carbonáticas como fonte do fluxo dissolvido remanescente, 

aumentando a alcalinidade da bacia e induzindo um fracionamento dos ETR semelhante ao 

que ocorre no oceano. Isto mostra que as concentrações de lantanídeos em rochas 

carbonáticas pré-cambrianas não é uma ferramenta inequívoca para identificação de 

ambientes marinhos abertos ou restritos, ou até mesmo para distinção de ambientes proximais 

e distais. 

 Além disso, as constantes anomalias positivas de Ce registradas nas rochas 

carbonáticas do Grupo Bambuí, sugerem constante anoxia das águas de fundo e baixa 

eficiência do sistema de circulação de massas de água da bacia. 

 

Rare earth elements of carbonate rocks from the Bambuí Group, southern São 

Francisco Basin, Brazil, and their significance as paleoenvironmental proxies 

 

Authors: Gustavo Macedo de Paula Santos
1 

(corresponding author), Sergio Caetano-Filho
1
, 

Marly Babinski
1
, Jacinta Enzweiler

2 

 



133 

 

1
 Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo; Rua do Lago, 562 – Cidade 

Universitária, São Paulo, Brazil – ZIP code 05508-080; gustavomps@yahoo.com.br 

2 
Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de Campinas 

 

Abstract 

 

We present new Rare Earth Elements plus Y (REE) data for the carbonate rocks of the 

Bambuí Group in the southern portion of the São Francisco basin. The behavior of the REE in 

the unit matches the C and Sr isotope variations that subdivide it in three Chemostratigraphic 

Intervals (CI-1 to CI-3). The lower CI-1 exhibit flat REE shale normalised distributions that 

record a high freshwater input in the basin after a glacial period. The following marine 

transgression diminished continental influence and initiated the development of La, Gd, and Y 

positive anomalies in the CI-2 samples. Interestingly, the appearance of a “seawater” type 

REE pattern is observed in the CI-3 samples when the São Francisco basin becomes 

restricted. Rather than open marine conditions, the CI-3 records a decrease in the silicate 

chemical weathering of sources located on the marginal belts of the São Francisco craton due 

to higher denudation rates and a change in the dissolved influx with preferential contribution 

from carbonate rocks. This resulted in a high concentration of carbonate ions in the restricted 

sea driving a REE fractionation process similar to the modern ocean. Constant positive 

Ce/Ce* values throughout the shallow and deep sections suggest anoxic early diagenetic 

conditions, inefficient circulation and stratified water column, which could have worked as a 

barrier for life diversification in the basin at the Ediacaran-Cambrian limit. Finally, our data 

show that REE concentrations of ancient biochemical environments are not an unequivocal 

tool neither to track open and restricted marine setting nor to distinguish proximal and distal 

environments. 

 

Keywords: REE, Ediacaran-Cambrian limit, marine proxies, paleoenvironments, 

paleoceanography 

       

1. Introduction 

 

Rare Earth Elements plus Yttrium (REE) concentrations of marine authigenic 

sediments in Precambrian successions have been widely used to track secular marine 

paleoenvironmental variations. Such changes in seawater chemistry are considered key pieces 

mailto:gustavomps@yahoo.com.br


134 

 

of the puzzle involving life evolution in our planet. This assumption is made based on a large 

number of works which report REE patterns in phosporites and carbonates of biogenic origin 

that closely resemble the ones of modern seawater and were deposited throughout the 

Archean, Paleoproterozoic, Neoproterozoic, and early Cambrian (i.e. Allwood et al., 2010; 

Kamber and Webb, 2001; Kamber et al., 2014; Nagarajan et al., 2011; Ling et al., 2013; 

Zhang et al., 2014). Such seawater like REE characteristics includes shale normalized 

depletion in light REE (LREE) related to heavy REE (HREE), a positive La anomaly, a 

negative Ce anomaly, a small Gd positive anomaly, and superchondritic Y/Ho ratios (Zhang 

and Nozaki, 1996). However, the degree of certainty that ancient authigenic sediments indeed 

record the composition of ancient seawater remains questionable, mainly due to two factors 

(Johannesson et al., 2006). The first reason is that many of marine biochemical sediments do 

not preserve REE contents of the precipitating water column owing to the diagenetic 

mobilization of the lanthanides, fractionation during mineral crystallization, and 

contamination by detrital components which are orders of magnitude more enriched in REE 

(Palmer, 1985; Palmer and Elderfield, 1986; Bau et al., 1996; Shields and Stille, 2001, 

Tostevin et al., 2016a). The second and most important reason is that many of terrestrial 

freshwaters (i.e. lakes, streams, rivers, groundwaters) display REE shale normalized 

distributions with the same characteristics mentioned above for seawater (Hoyle et al., 1984; 

Goldstein and Jacobson, 1988; Johannesson and Lyon, 1994; Johannesson et al., 1997; 

Johannesson et al. 2006; Dia et al., 2000; Négrel et al., 2000; Hagedorn et al., 2011). This 

similarity can be explained by the chemical behaviour of REE in solution, which has a close 

relationship with pH. In alkaline waters (such as seawater or alkaline lakes) lanthanides form 

complexes with carbonate ions forming Ln(CO3)2
-
. The HREE complexes are more stable 

than the LREE and thus more soluble, which causes the solution to be progressively depleted 

in LREE (Cantrell and Byrne, 1987; Johannesson and Lyon 1994; Quinn et al., 2004). 

Similarly, in acidic waters the formed HREE(CO3)
+
 compounds are more stable and soluble 

than LREE(CO3)
+
, also leading to LREE depletion (Verplanck et al., 2004; Hagedorn et al., 

2011). In diluted and circum neutral waters stability of both LREE and HREE are similar so 

there is no fractionation between them resulting in waters with flat type shale normalized REE 

distributions or slightly LREE enriched (Lawrence et al., 2006). La is an exception among the 

LREE, as its empty 4f electron shell provides great stability in solution (Byrne and Kim, 

1990; De Baar et al., 1991). Y is also more stable in solution than the other trivalent 

lanthanides and is scavenged from the water column two times slower than Ho, which causes 

the superchondritc Y/Ho ratios observed in seawater (Nozaki et al., 1997). 



135 

 

In conclusion, provided ideal conditions (~6.45 > pH > 7.75, Hagedorn et al., 2011) 

any water body can present the “seawater like” REE patterns, which implies serious caution 

on identifying ancient marine environments via REE compositions. Even the differentiation 

between proximal and distal environments, as well as restricted and open marine 

environments (for examples see Frimmel, 2009; Madhavaraju and González-Léon, 2011; 

Zhang et al., 2014) requires attention as ocean-margins and shoreline/enclosed bays waters 

may display similar REE patterns to the open ocean, even with lower anomalies intensities 

(Johannesson et al., 2006). 

Another use regarding REE studies in ancient carbonate rocks is the Ce/Ce* anomaly. 

In oxic aquatic environments such as the modern ocean, the Ce
3+

 is oxidized into Ce
4+

 which 

is less soluble and readily removed from water column adsorbed onto Fe-Mn oxides and 

hydroxides (Elderfield and Greaves, 1981; German and Elderfield, 1990; Bau et al. 1996, 

Lawrence and Kamber, 2006), therefore producing the Ce negative anomaly. Due to such 

distinct behaviour Ce was considered a valuable proxy for tracing seawater redox state. Not 

surprisingly, Archean, Paleoproterozoic, and most Neoproterozoic biochemical sediments are 

devoid of such negative anomalies as dissolved oxygen present in aquatic environments was 

not sufficient to oxidize Ce (Derry and Jacobson, 1990; Shimizu et al., 1990; Danielson et al., 

1992; Bau and Möler, 1993; Kamber and Webb, 2001; Van Kranendonk et al., 2003; Bolhar 

et al., 2004). Reports of carbonates with Ce negative anomalies start to appear at the 

Ediacaran-Cambrian transition. Ling et al. (2013) report Ce/Ce* values as low as 0.4 for 

Dengying and Yanjiahe formations suggesting oxygenation of shallow waters, which in turn 

is linked to appearance of biota at the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary. Whether this is a global 

feature or not remains unclear as other studies on carbonate successions of the same age based 

on different proxies do not show such oxygenation event. For example, Johnston et al. (2013) 

show through C and S isotopes combined with Fe speciation in Ediacaran carbonates from 

northwest Canada, that no oxygenation event occurred in that basin. Differences in the 

depositional setting could generate such discrepancies so that these proxies reflect different 

local conditions. Furthermore, Ce in carbonates tend to be in equilibrium with bottom waters 

during early diagenesis, so that the Ce anomaly reflects the composition of these waters and 

the circulation efficiency of the basin instead of the redox state of the whole water column 

(German and Elderfield, 1990; Haley et al., 2004). 

At the light of the debate above, we present REE data for the carbonates of the 

Ediacaran-Cambrian Bambuí Group sampled at the southern sector of the São Francisco 

Basin, southeast Brazil (Fig. 1). The unit is subdivided into three Chemostratigraphy Intervals 



136 

 

(CI) which record distinct phases of the basin (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). Although the 

significance of the basal CI-1 remains to be understood, CI-2 and CI-3 are extremely valuable 

for testing the efficacy to trace open vs. restricted marine settings and proximal vs. distal 

environments in ancient carbonates. They reflect the transition from a stage connected with 

other West Gondwana sea basins, in which seawater exchange and isotope homogenization 

took place, to a restricted stage, when the isotope and geochemical pool of the São Francisco 

Basin was disconnected from the global ocean (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). The new data also 

provide further insights on the evolution of the basin and on the seawater composition in 

continental settings during the Ediacaran-Cambrian transition. 

 

2. Geological Setting 

 

The São Francisco basin deposits cover more than 300,000 km
2
 of the homonymous 

craton in east Central Brazil (Fig. 1). The Archean-Paleoproterozoic basement is exposed both 

at the southern and northeast areas of the craton (Teixeira et al., 2000; Alkmim and Martins-

Neto, 2012). 

The Neoproterozoic sedimentary units of the basin comprise sparse glacial units of 

mainly continental origin of the Jequitaí Formation on the base (Rocha-Campos et al., 1981; 

Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Martins-Neto and Hercos, 2002) and the overlying marine 

siliciclastic-carbonate sediments of the Bambuí Group (Fig. 2, Dardenne, 1978; Vieira et al. 

2007; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). Although some tectonic discontinuities such as 

thrust faults along craton margins may difficult relationship observations, the glacial unit has 

equivalents on the surrounding mobile belts: the Macaúbas Group on the Araçuaí orogen and 

the Ibiá Group on the Brasília Belt (Uhlein et al., 1999; Dardenne, 2000; Martins-Neto et al., 

2001; Pedrosa-Soares et al., 2011; Babinski et al., 2012). 



137 

 

 

Fig. 1 – Geological maps of the West Gondwana at ca. 540 Ma, the São Francisco Craton (modified from Alkmim et al., 2006) and the studied area 

with locations of the sampled sections from the Bambuí Group. SJL: São José da Lapa, IN: Inhaúma, SC: Sopé da Cruz, HV: Haras Veredas, MT: 

Matozinhos, SL: Sete Lagoas, SH: Serra de Santa Helena carbonate sample, FAS: Fazenda Água Santa, LJ: Lagoa do Jacaré. 



138 

 

The Bambuí Group records a marine transgression over a foreland basin set up on the 

craton due to the overload caused by both Brasília and Araçuaí belts onto the cratonic borders 

(Martins-Neto et al., 2001; Alkmim and Martins-Neto, 2012). The unit outcrops along the N-

S segment of the cratonic area and the western Brasília belt, but not on the eastern Araçuaí 

belt (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2008, 2011; Babinski et al., 2012). In the studied area, the Bambuí 

Group sharply overlies the Archean-Paleoproterozoic basement in most of locations, and only 

in some restricted localities such as São José da Lapa and Inhaúma cities it overlies the 

Carrancas Formation. This last unit comprises conglomerates and siltites, considered to be 

also an equivalent of the Jequitaí Formation on the cratonic area (Dardenne, 1978; Vieira et 

al., 2007) or the base of the Bambuí Group (Caxito et al., 2012). Shear zones marked by well-

developed foliation and stretching lineation separate basement and Neoproterozoic-Cambrian 

covers. The metamorphism is low grade and there are well preserved carbonate layers 

between shear zones and far from the marginal fold and thrust belts. 

The most accepted stratigraphy for the Bambuí Group was proposed by Dardenne 

(1978). This author subdivided the unit in five formations namely, from base to top (Fig. 2): 

(i) the Sete Lagoas Formation, which comprises limestones and dolomites with interbedded 

pelitic rocks layers (thickness ? 500 m); (ii) the Serra de Santa Helena Formation, mainly 

composed of shales and siltstones with interbedded limestones and sandstones (640 m); (iii) 

the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation, which displays limestones, siltstones, and marlstones (350 

m); (iv) the Serra da Saudade Formation, constituted of siltstones, green shales, and a few 

limestone layers (200 m); and (v) the Três Marias Formation, composed of arkosic sandstones 

and siltstones (100 m). These are the maximum thicknesses which were described by Iglesias 

and Uhlein (2009). 

Based on the C and Sr isotopes records from the carbonate rocks of the Bambuí 

Group, Paula-Santos et al. (2017) defined three Chemostratigraphic Intervals (CI), each one 

corresponding to a different geological stage concerning connection and restriction of the 

basin (Fig. 2). The lower CI-1 comprises the cap carbonates of the Sete Lagoas Formation 

which displays ?
13

C values as low as -5‰ (V-PDB) and 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios between 0.7074 and 

0.7082 (Babinski et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007). These isotope values were interpreted as a 

transition from a restricted to a marine connected setting in response to a transgression that 

flooded the São Francisco Craton (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). Such event may have occurred 

in the aftermath of a glaciation, which age is still a matter of debate. Three are the possible 

ages: (i) Sturtian, based on a Pb-Pb isochron age at 740 ± 22 Ma on the overlying carbonates 

(Babinski et al., 2007); (ii) Marinoan (~635 Ma), proposed based on isotope 



139 

 

chemostratigraphy of carbonates from the Bambuí Group (Caxito et al., 2012; Alvarenga et 

al., 2014; Uhlein et al., 2016); (iii) and late Ediacaran (post-Gaskiers), supported by fossil and 

detrital zircon U-Pb data from rocks of the CI-2 and CI-3, together with lack of erosional 

surface and isotopic secular variations that could account for an expressive depositional hiatus 

between CI-1 and CI-2 (Kuchenbecker et al., 2016; Paula-Santos et al., 2017). The CI-2 

matches the middle portion of the Sete Lagoas Formation, with carbonates that yield ?
13

C 

values varying in a narrow range around 0‰, 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7082, and bares the 

index fossil Cloudina sp..This interval marks the onset of sea pathway connecting the São 

Francisco basin to other late Ediacaran marine basins in the West Gondwana (Warren et al., 

2014, Paula-Santos et al., 2017). The uppermost CI-3 comprises the upper Sete Lagoas, Serra 

de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations (the Serra da Saudade and Três Marias 

formations are not in this chemostratigraphic subdivision due to lack of isotope data). 

Carbonates from this interval yield very positive ?
13

C values (up to +16‰; Iyer et al., 1995) 

and low radiogenic 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios around 0.7075 (Misi et al., 2007; Caxito et al., 2012; 

Alvarenga et al., 2007; 2014; Kuchenbecker et al., 2016; Paula-Santos et al., 2015, 2017) 

which do not match the values proposed for the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary in several Sr 

evolution curves (e.g. Jacobson and Kaufmann, 1999; Halverson et al., 2010; Kuznetsov et 

al., 2013) and record the demise of the sea pathway connection and completely restriction of 

the basin. Paula-Santos et al. (2015) obtained a maximum depositional age of 560 Ma based 

on the most representative U-Pb age population of detrital zircon, but also retrieved zircon 

grains younger than 540 Ma. Therefore, considering these age provenances and the presence 

of Cloudina sp. in the lower carbonates (CI-2), it is possible to assume that these rocks may 

be Cambrian in age.

the basal Sete Lagoas Formation.

2.1. Sampled sections 

 

For this study, 38 carbonate samples from 8 carbonate sections of the Bambuí Group 

(Sete Lagoas and Lagoa do Jacaré formations) plus 1 sample from Serra de Santa Helena 

Formation were selected (Fig. 1). For complete stratigraphic, petrological, geochemical, and 

isotope characterization of the sections see Paula-Santos et al. (2017). 

Samples from SJL and IN sections belong to the basal CI-1. SJL samples are impure 

gray limestones deposited in shallow carbonate platform, whereas the IN sample is pink 

impure limestone retrieved from a carbonate lens interbedded within siltites deposited over 

basement highs in Inhaúma city area. These carbonates display very negative ?
13

C values as 

low as -5‰ and are above diamictites and siltites from the Carrancas Formation.  

The section SC comprises 36 m of little impure grey limestones (5-10% of detrital 

content) displaying mainly truncated lamination with cross stratification and some 

occurrences of authigenic pyrite. All samples from this section, except SC-25, belong to the 

connected CI-2 stage and were deposited in a shallow carbonate platform. Upwards, these 

carbonate rocks show progressively more planar lamination, darker grey colour and less 

detrital content indicating transition to CI-3 (sample SC-25). 

Samples from sections HV, MT and SL, and sample SC-25 belong to the Sete Lagoas 

Formation CI-3 restricted stage. Those are dark grey to black limestones, with very few 

siliciclastic content admixed to the carbonate matrix (<5%) and display mainly plane-parallel 

lamination. Section HV is located on the eastern margin of the basin and was subject to 

freshwater influence as shown by large fluctuations the in ?
13

C values, 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios, and 

geochemical contents (Guacaneme et al., submitted). The MT section was deposited in deeper 

environments, below the base of influence of waves and storms and with little to negligible 

freshwater influence based on isotope geochemical data. SL was deposited in shallower 

settings close to the Sete Lagoas basement high. 

The sample SH-02 was retrieved from a dark carbonate layer interbedded in the Serra 

the Santa Helena pelites, and samples from sections FAS and LJ were collected in outcrops 

from the Lagoa do Jacaré Formation. Both units also belong to the restricted CI-3 stage 

(Paula-Santos et al., 2017). The FAS section consists in a tilted 23 m thick block of dark 

carbonates with light brown siltites at the base and top. Mudstone intraclasts are commonly 

found within the carbonate matrix. The LJ (Lagoa do Jacaré) section crops out by the BR-135 

road (km 662 – Fig. 1). Dark carbonates layers (1-4 m thick) with oolites (sample LJ-12), 



142 

 

heterolitic lamination (samples LJ-03 and 05), and cross stratification occur interbedded with 

light brown siltites and sandstones. 

 

3. Analytical procedures 

 

Sub-samples of carbonate powders were obtained by crushing fresh pieces of rock in 

an agate mortar. The selected pieces were devoid of fractures, veins, weathering, and mineral 

filling, in order to avoid possible post depositional alterations in the REE record. 

A two-step leaching procedure was applied to the 38 selected carbonate samples. The first 

consisted in leaching a ~50 mg aliquot of each the sample powder with 0.1 mol/L HCl for one 

hour, in order to dissolve about 15% of the carbonate mass. The slurry was centrifuged, the 

supernatant discarded and rinsed three times with ultrapure water (Milli-Q, Millipore). All 

washing solutions were discarded. After drying, the residue underwent a second leaching with 

1 mol/L HCl solution for 30 minutes that dissolved 70% of the remaining sample mass. After 

centrifuging, the supernatant was retrieved and the solid residue rinsed three times with 

ultrapure water. All washing supernatants were added to the leachate solution. After drying on 

a hot plate, the residue was converted into nitrates by adding 0.5 mL of HNO3. The solution 

was evaporated again and the residue was dissolved in 3% (v/v) HNO3 for the REE 

determinations. The measurements were carried out by inductively coupled plasma mass 

spectrometry (ICP-MS) on a field sector Element XR (Thermo, Germany) at the Institute of 

Geosciences of University of Campinas (Unicamp), Brazil. The instrument was calibrated 

with a series of standard solutions prepared by dilution of certified reference materials 

(Accustandard, USA). For quality control, the certified reference material of river water 

SLRS-5 (NRC-CNRC, Canada) was measured during the analytical runs. Obtained values for 

the REE were within the confidence interval of the compiled values (Yeghicheyan et al., 

2013). 

For comparison purposes, the whole rock samples were also analysed. Powdered test-

portions (0.2 g) were fused with lithium metaborate/tertraborate, followed by melt dissolution 

with dilute nitric acid. Major and trace elements were determined by ICP-OES and ICP-MS, 

respectively, at Acme and ALS Global laboratories. The obtained REE concentrations were 

normalised to the Post Archean Australian Shale (PAAS) values from McLennan (1989). 

REE anomalies were calculated as REEn/REEn*, where REEn* is the expected normalised 

concentration when interpolated with proper neighbours. REEn/REEn* values below 0.90 or 

above 1.10 were considered anomalies. The REEn* values were calculated using the equations 



143 

 

for geometric average proposed by Lawrence et al. (2006), as our data patterns behave more 

smoothly in log-linear plots. The equations are the following: 

 

 Lan* = Prn x (Prn/Ndn)

(Nd/Yb)n and (Pr/Yb)n ratios were used to describe LREE/HREE enrichment/depletion as 

these elements are not supposed to behave anomalously in aquatic systems (Johannesson et 

al., 2006; Lawrence et al., 2006). For the same reason, (Pr/Tb)n and (Tb/Yb)n were calculated 

to describe LREE/MREE and MREE/HREE relationships, according to Lawrence et al. 

(2006).  

 

4. Results 

 

The values obtained of major (Al) and trace elements (Zr and REE) in the carbonate 

fraction of the samples obtained by the two-step leaching are presented in Table 1. The 

meaningful results obtained in whole rock analyses are presented in Table 2 and compared 

with the two-step leaching results of the carbonate fraction of the respective samples. The 

relative concentration of each element in the leachate fractions compared to the bulk samples 

depends on element and sampling section. The ?REEleach/??REEbulk percentage drops from 

30% in samples of the CI-1 and CI-2 to 15% for CI-3 samples. 

The La, Ce, Eu, and Gd anomalies, Y/Ho ratios and other shale normalised ratios of 

the leachate fractions are presented in Table 3 only for samples with Sc <0.2 ?g/g, chosen as 

a cut off to avoid data with possible shale contamination (see discussion in item 6.1).  

Samples from CI-1 have the highest ?REE ranging from 10.74 to 29.23 ?g/g (average 

= 19.57 ?g/g, n=4). The samples of the same section have the highest values of Al and Zr, 

varying between 0.92 and 1.51% and 24 and 33 ?g/g, respectively (Table 1). Sc 

concentrations range from 0.09 to 0.94 ?g/g. Samples considered free of shale contamination 

display (Nd/Yb)n and (Pr/Yb)n averages (n=2) of 1.27 and 1.20, respectively (Table 3), 

indicating enrichment in LREE compared to HREE, which can be seen in the shale 

normalized distributions (Fig. 3a). Although the (Pr/Tb)n average shows no anomaly (1.00, 



144 

 

Table 3), (Tb/Yb)n ratio averages 1.20 and confirm the MREE enrichment over HREE. The 

average calculated anomalies for the samples for the basal CI-1 were 1.68 for La/La*, 1.12 for 

Ce/Ce*, 1.17 for Eu/Eu*, and 1.28 for Gd/Gd* (Table 3). The Y/Ho ratios and the (Y/Ho)n 

anomaly are the weakest among all samples with averages of 32.84 and 1.21, respectively.  

The carbonate samples of CI-2 show ?REE between 1.83 and 18.37 ?g/g (average = 

8.67 ?g/g, n=5), with Al concentrations ranging from 0.61 to 0.94% and Zr from 14 to 35 

?g/g (Table 1). The Sc concentrations vary between 0.06-0.65 ?g/g. Samples that contain Sc 

below the cut off value (0.2 ?g/g ) have a higher LREE/HREE enrichment compared to the 

basal CI, as shown by (Nd/Yb)n and (Pr/Yb)n averages equal to 1.47 and 1.51 (n=3), 

respectively (Table 3). The average of (Pr/Tb)n equal to 1.21 and of (Tb/Yb)n equal to 1.26 

indicate a progressively depletion from LREE to HREE. Such trend appears in the shale 

normalized plots that also show La, Gd, and Y anomalies (Fig. 3b). The averages of the 

calculated anomalies were higher than CI-1: 2.16 for La/La*, 1.18 for Ce/Ce* and 1.34 for 

Gd/Gd*. Eu/Eu* was the exception with a 1.10 average (Table 3). The Y/Ho and (Y/Ho)n 

ratios were also higher than the basal carbonates, displaying mean values of 39.78 and 1.46, 

respectively. 

The majority of the samples belong to the CI-3 (n=28) and all of them have Sc <0.2 

?g/g cut off. For data evaluation and interpretation, we separated the CI-3 samples in two 

groups: (i) samples from Sete Lagoas Formation (sections MT, SL, HV and sample SC-25); 

(ii) samples from Serra de Santa Helena (SH-02) and Lagoa do Jacaré Formation (sections LJ 

and FAS). CI-3 samples from the Sete Lagoas Formation have the lowest ?REE, Al and Zr 

concentrations, which minimum and maximum values are 0.24-3.33 ?g/g, 0.01-0.23%, and 

0.5-30 ?g/g, respectively (Table 1). The calculated anomalies and ratios seem lower than 

those of CI-2 at a first glance, but a closer look reveal important differences depending on the 

paleogeographic position of the sections. Sections HV and SL are located at the eastern 

margin of the basin and close to the Sete Lagoas high, respectively (Fig. 1). Samples from 

these sections display calculated averages of 1.69 for La/La*, 1.46 for Ce/Ce*, 1.46 for 

Eu/Eu*, and 1.11 for Gd/Gd* (n=13; normalized distributions in Fig. 3c). Combining sample 

SC-25 to samples from MT section (Fig. 3d), all of them deposited in deeper settings, La/La* 

and Ce/Ce* anomalies are higher with respectively averages of 2.23 and 1.54, but Eu/Eu* and 

Gd/Gd* values of 0.87 and 0.96, respectively (n=8; Table 3). It is noteworthy the negative Eu 

anomalies found on samples MT-07 and MT-15, which exhibit Eu/Eu* values of 0.30 and 

0.16, respectively.  Significant differences are also observed in the Y/Ho and (Y/Ho)n ratios. 



145 

 

The mean values for the proximal sections are 36.53 and 1.34, respectively, whereas the mean 

values for deeper sections are respectively 55.77 and 2.05. However, no significant 

differences are observed in the LREE/MREE/HREE proportions and all sections from Sete 

Lagoas Formation display HREE enrichment over LREE (Table 3; Fig. 3c and d). The 

calculated averages for (Nd/Yb)n, (Pr/Yb)n, (Pr/Tb)n, (Tb/Yb)n for the samples are 0.73, 

0.60, 0.55, and 1.07, respectively.  

CI-3 samples from Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré Formation have ?REE 

ranging from 0.53 to 15.51 ?g/g, Al concentrations from 0.16 to 0.95% and Zr concentrations 

from 5 to 30 ?g/g (Table 1). The average of the calculated anomalies (n=7) are 2.18 for 

La/La*, 1.19 for Ce/Ce*, 1.18 for Eu/Eu*, and 1.22 for Gd/Gd* (Table 3). The mean values 

of Y/Ho and (Y/Ho)n ratios are 40.32 and 1.48, respectively. Calculations and shale 

normalized distributions show absence of LREE/HREE enrichment or depletion and slight 

overall MREE enrichment over LREE and HREE (Table 3; Fig. 3e). The averages for 

(Nd/Yb)n, (Pr/Yb)n, (Pr/Tb)n, (Tb/Yb)n for the samples are 0.73, 0.58, 0.54, and 1.03, 

respectively.

5. Discussion 

 

5.1. Shale contamination and post-depositional alteration assessment 

 



152 

 

Silicate minerals are often much more enriched in REE than the carbonate minerals. 

Therefore, the dissolution of the detrital fraction during the leaching procedure could mask 

the original seawater REE record in the samples (e.g. Ling et al., 2013; Zhou et al., 2012; 

Tostevin et al., 2016a). Moreover, during diagenesis part of the REE from silicates may be 

transferred to secondary carbonate phases (Shields and Stille, 2001) even considering that 

REE are not easily mobilized after deposition (Webb et al., 2009). Checking the 

concentrations of Al and Zr in the bulk rock and Sc obtained in the leachate fraction analyzed 

can help to identify these processes. Positive correlations between Al, Zr, or Sc and the ?REE 

could suggest contamination from shale either via diagenesis or acid attack (Kamber and 

Webb, 2001; Nothdurft et al., 2004). 

Al vs. ?REE, Zr vs. ?REE, and Sc vs. ?REE plots show positive correlations (R
2
 of 

0.79, 0.43 and 0.61, respectively Fig. 4). Although these calculations indicate contamination 

from shale during the applied leaching procedure, the plots show that samples with higher 

amount of Al, Zr and Sc (therefore with higher detrital proportion) force the positive 

correlation. Some cut offs were tested to check if samples with lower detrital content are 

devoid of contamination. When only samples with Al <0.7%, Zr <10 ?g/g, or Sc <0.2 ?g/g 

are considered, the Al vs. ?REE, Zr vs. ?REE, and Sc vs. ?REE plots show absence of 

correlation and the R
2 

drop to 0.11, 0.05 and 0.20, respectively (statistically significant). 

These values are low enough to consider the lack or negligible contamination of leachates 

from shale. Here we used only the Sc cut off as it was the only screening proxy measured 

directly at the carbonate leached fraction. In this way, we could trace both any silicate 

dissolution during acid leaching as well as a monitor of REE uptake by secondary carbonates 

during diagenesis. 

The initial positive correlations could suggest that the acid used in this work (1 mol/L 

HCl) was too strong to dissolve carbonate rocks for REE determinations. However, two 

arguments point otherwise. First, we note that our Al cut off value twice that used by Ling et 

al. (2013), even using a stronger acid than the 1 mol/L acetic acid used in their leaching 

procedures. Additionally, we always adjusted the acid amount to react with no more than 70% 

of the remaining sample after the first leaching. The total leached mass (considering the 2 

steps) was not larger than 78% of the total sample mass and none of the samples had more 

than 10% of detrital content. Second, the ?REEleach/??REEbulk percentage proportions (Table 

2) decrease significantly from samples of CI-1 and CI-2 (> 30%) to the samples of CI-3 (<

15%), implying that any silicate attack was not systematic. Therefore, we suggest that 



153 

 

samples with Sc > 0.2 ?g/g were more likely alterated by diagenesis than an analytical 

artifact. 

A further step into post-depositional alteration screening is identifying diagenetic 

effects in the Ce and Eu concentrations of the samples, which are crucial to our 

paleoenvironmental interpretations. Shields and Stille (2001) concluded that, under diagenetic 

ion exchange, REE compositions of marine precipitates become progressively enriched in Ce 

and depleted in Eu. Also, (Dy/Sm)n ratios of the rocks decrease, so that Ce/Ce* vs. (Dy/Sm)n 

and Ce/Ce* vs. Eu/Eu* negative correlations would track such post-depositional 

modifications. Our plots applied to samples with Sc <0.2 ?g/g reveal a positive correlation 

(R
2
 = 0.59) for Ce/Ce* vs. (Dy/Sm)n and no correlation (R

2
 = 0.04) for Ce/Ce* vs. Eu/Eu* 

(Fig. 5). We conclude that the selected samples may have preserved the original REE 

compositions. 



154 

 

 

 

Fig. 4 – Al, Zr and Sc vs.??REE plots for the studied carbonate rock samples leached with 0.1 mol/L HCl. Note that when Al <0.7%, Zr <10 ?g/g or Sc <0.2

155 

 

 

Fig. 5 – (Dy/Sm)n and Eu/Eu* vs. Ce/Ce* dispersion diagrams for the studied samples. No diagenetic

5.2. REE seawater composition of the São Francisco basin 

 

The carbonate rocks considered to retain the original seawater composition provide 

important insights on the São Francisco basin evolution. In fact, there are notable changes in 

the REE compositions among samples from the different Chemostratigraphic Intervals, 



156 

 

matching the C (Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Vieira et al., 2007) and Sr 

(Paula-Santos et al., 2017) isotope variations observed through the Bambuí Group (Fig. 2). 

The CI-1 represents the deposition of a distinctive layer of dolostones and limestones 

(cap carbonates) probably in the aftermath of a glaciation (Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et 

al., 2007, 2014; Vieira et al., 2007). Although the age of these carbonate rocks remain 

controversial, the melt of ice sheets during deglaciation might have delivered large amounts 

of freshwater into the basin (Kuchenbecker et al., 2016). This scenario seems compatible with 

our REE data. The flat type patterns of the shale normalised diagrams (Fig. 3), the high ?REE 

and the LREE enrichment relative to HREE observed in the carbonate samples from the CI-1 

are also a common feature in many freshwaters (Johannesson et al., 1997; Lawrence et al., 

2006; Garcia et al., 2007). We note, however, two distinctive features: La positive anomalies, 

although lower than La/La* value of 2.6 for modern ocean (Lawrence et al., 2006); and 

variable Y/Ho ratios with sample SJL-12 yielding a value close to the PAAS standard (~27, 

McLennan, 1989) and sample SJL-06 with a significant positive (Y/Ho)n and Y/Ho ~36, 

higher than the PAAS (Table 3; Fig 6). La has a greater stability in solution due to its empty 

4f electron shell (Byrne and Kim, 1990; De Baar et al., 1991) and Y is also more stable in 

solution (Lawrence and Kamber, 2006). The different behaviours from these elements could 

account for the La/La* and (Y/Ho)n positive anomalies, as long as enough time is given for 

such processes. The CI-1 samples also display a slight positive Ce/Ce* (~1.12; Table 3), 

which may suggest lack of oxidation of Ce
3+

. Also, the amount of REE dissolved in sediment 

pore water is much higher than the overlying water column (Elderfield and Sholkovitz, 1987; 

Sholkovitz and Elderfield, 1988; German and Elderfield, 1990; Sholkovitz et al., 1989) and 

the REE pattern that prevails in authigenic sediments is usually the one of the waters in the 

sediment/water interface (Haley et al., 2004). So the positive Ce anomaly is most likely an 

indicator of anoxic conditions of bottom water of penecontemporaneous / early diagenetic 

paleoenvironments (German and Elderfield, 1990). 

The transition to CI-2 is marked by an increase in the La/La* values from 1.68 to 2.16 

(mean values), in the Gd/Gd* values from 1.28 to 1.34, in the (Y/Ho)n ratios from 1.21 to 

1.46, and in the Y/Ho ratios from 33 to 40 (Table 3; Fig. 6). This could suggest the onset of 

more marine conditions as the REE data for CI-2 resemble closely the modern ocean seawater 

(Zhang and Nozaki, 1996; Lawrence et al., 2006). This process may be the result of the 

connection of the São Francisco basin with other marine settings in the West Gondwana due 

to transgression started at the CI-1. It matches the evolution recorded in the C and Sr isotope 

composition of the carbonate rocks from the Bambuí Group. A sharp increase in ?
13

C values 



157 

 

in CI-1 from -5‰ (after a negative excursion) to values around 0‰ that persists through the 

CI-2, which is accompanied by a positive excursion in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios from 0.7074 to 

0.7082 that also spans through the base and middle portions of the CI-2 (Paula-Santos et al., 

2017), mark the transition between these chemostratigraphic intervals. Both isotope and REE 

data seem to converge to an interpretation of progressive lower influence of freshwater 

upwards in the lower Sete Lagoas Formation as the sea level rose and basin connection was 

achieved.  

Nevertheless, we note one important feature: the samples from CI-2 display 

enrichment in LREE over HREE, with progressive depletion from LREE to HREE (Table 3; 

Fig. 3b), which differs from the modern seawater. Calculations of R
2
 (not shown) of La/La* 

vs. (Nd/Yb)n, Gd/Gd* vs. (Nd/Yb)n and Y/Ho vs. (Nd/Yb)n for the CI-2 carbonate rocks are 

equal to 0.93, 0.70 and 1.00, respectively. Although it could mean that the development of La 

and Gd positive anomalies as well as the increase in the Y/Ho ratios derive from different 

proportions of freshwater delivered to the basin, these calculations result from only three 

samples. Anyway, impure carbonates deposited in an epicontinental shallow environment 

(Kuchenbecker et al., 2016; Paula-Santos et al., 2017) suggest large influence of freshwater in 

this stage which is compatible with the LREE/HREE relationships. The greater stability in 

solution of La (Byrne and Kim, 1990; De Baar et al., 1991), Gd (Johannesson et al., 1997) 

and Y (Lawrence and Kamber, 2006) may have led to higher concentrations of these elements 

in the basin, buffering them against freshwater influence. Alternatively, this LREE/HREE 

enrichment may reflect bacterial sulphate reduction in the sediment / water interface (Kim et 

al., 2012). This biogeochemical process is also evidenced by the occurrence of authigenic 

pyrite in the CI-2 samples. It alone cannot produce the La, Gd, and Y positive anomalies, but 

to a lesser extent it could be responsible for LREE enrichment over HREE.  

The CI-2 is also characterized by a higher Ce/Ce* positive anomaly than CI-1(1.18, 

Table 3) suggesting progressive Ce accumulation in bottom waters due to anoxia. Anoxic 

diagenesis is common in shallow platforms where the inefficient circulation is less capable of 

bringing oxygenated waters to deeper environments (German and Elderfield, 1990). Both CI-

1 and CI-2 samples display light positive Eu anomalies, but they seem to be a result of a small 

Sm negative anomaly (Fig. 3a and b).  



158 

 

 

 

Fig. 6 – La/La* vs. Ce/Ce*, (Nd/Yb)n and Y/Ho, Y/Ho vs. (Nd/Yb)n and Ce/Ce* and Ce/Ce* vs. (Nd/Yb)n for CI-1, CI-2 and CI-3 (from shallow and deep 

environments) carbonate rocks of the Bambuí Group. 



159 

 

Major changes in the C isotope composition (Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos 

et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007), 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios, and overall elementary chemistry of seawater 

(Paula-Santos et al., 2017) appear in the CI-2 to CI-3 transition. They mark the demise of the 

West Gondwana sea pathway that connected the São Francisco basin to external seawaters, 

establishing a restricted epicontinental environment.  The comparison between the CI-2 and 

the deeper SC and MT sections of CI-3 also reveal a major change in the REE composition in 

seawater (Fig. 6). The carbonate rocks from the upper interval display high La/La* values 

(mean value of 2.23, Table 3), high (Y/Ho)n anomalies (2.05), chondritic Y/Ho ratios (~55), 

and a marked depletion in LREE relative to HREE that resemble a normalized distribution 

pattern (Fig. 3c, d, and e) of the modern ocean (Zhang and Nozaki, 1996). Gd/Gd* values are 

the only exception as the mean values show no anomaly (0.97, Table 3). This result is 

unexpected, as the development of “seawater” pattern in the Bambuí Group occurs with the 

restriction of the basin, rather than an open ocean or connected phase. To understand this 

feature we examine the tectonic framework and isotope record of the CI-3 stage and link them 

to the fractionation process of the REE. 

The main hypothesis for the restriction of the São Francisco basin around the 

Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary is the uplift of the marginal orogenic belts of the homonymous 

craton (Paula-Santos et al., 2015). U-Pb ages in detrital zircons support this as they show a 

change from a wide range of Tonian, Mesoproterozoic, and Paleoproterozoic sources in the 

CI-2 to a foreland distribution pattern dominated by Ediacaran sources in the CI-3 (Pimentel 

et al., 2011; Paula-Santos et al., 2015). Such uplift caused not only restriction but also 

steepened topography on the source areas, which led to shorter time for water/rock interaction 

in the orogens, favouring carbonate chemical weathering over silicate (Palmer and Edmond, 

1992; Blum et al., 1998) and producing the major decrease in the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios and the 

increase in [Sr] (Paula-Santos et al., 2015). This process might have delivered carbonate ions 

to the basin which is crucial to the REE fractionation. As the concentration of (CO3)
2-

 

increases in seawater, so does the amount of Ln(CO3)2
-
. The stability of the HREE carbonate 

complexes in solution is about two orders higher than the LREE, thus resulting in LREE 

depletion (Cantrell and Byrne, 1987; Johannesson and Lyon 1994; Quinn et al., 2004). 

Underground water discharge from aquifers hosted in the underlying CI-2 carbonate rocks 

may also have contributed with carbonate ions. We also note that the steepened topography 

significantly decreases the REE influx into the basin. The shorter water/rock interaction time 

in mountain areas limits the contribution of granitic rock to the runoff REE (Garcia et al., 

2007). Felsic rocks are 30 to 40 times more enriched in REE than carbonates, so that 2% 



160 

 

contribution of these lithotypes to the influx into restricted or proximal environments would 

be enough to suppress the LREE depletion (Johannesson et al., 1997). It suggests a 

pronounced decrease of silicate weathering in source areas, probably also intensified by 

higher denudation rates. The source change indicated by the geochronological data coincides 

with a change in the sedimentary filling of the basin. The CI-2 is dominantly carbonatic 

whereas the CI-3 stage has a large siliciclastic influx recorded mainly in Serra de Santa 

Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations with carbonates deposited in shallower areas (mainly 

upper Sete Lagoas and Lagoa do Jacaré formations; Reis and Suss, 2016). Both 

geochronological and sedimentary data suggest increased denudation rates during CI-3 

deposition, depleting fresh material available for weathering in source areas, thus creating a 

weathering limited regime and decreasing dissolved influx from silicates (Bouchez et al., 

2014).  

Therefore, we interpret the “seawater” signal from the REE concentrations of CI-3 

samples as result of combined low REE influx from silicates and input of carbonate ions from 

weathered carbonate rocks and aquifers in a restricted basin, creating conditions for a REE 

fractionation similar to the modern ocean. A modern example of similar scenario is the Mono 

Lake, USA (Johannesson and Lyons, 1994). Although surrounded mostly by silicate rocks, 

the main influx to lake comes from carbonate sources. The outcome is that the Ln(CO3)2
-
 in 

Mono Lake is thousand times higher than the modern ocean and the shale normalized 

distributions resembles the one from the modern ocean with LREE depletion. The ?REE from 

the lake and the deeper settings from CI-3 (mean value of 0.55 ?g/g; Table 3) are also very 

low. Samples from Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations also have similar 

REE characteristics (Table 3; Fig. 3e) so that no major changes in seawater composition are 

recorded and the inclusion of these units in the CI-3 is pertinent. Additionally, the 

paleogeographic position of the São Francisco Craton in the very core of the West Gondwana 

continent (Fig.1) could also have caused changes in climate, with less influence from oceanic 

humid air masses and dryer conditions. Higher evaporation rates could have increased salinity 

and alkalinity of seawater, helping REE fractionation. This is similar to hypersaline lakes 

such as Salgada Lake in southeast Brazil (Birgel et al., 2015), which is also characterized by 

very positive ?
13

C values similarly to the Bambuí Group. Although hypersaline conditions are 

not known in the São Francisco Basin, calcite and dolomite are the first minerals to precipitate 

in the evaporitic series. This paleoclimatic scenario should be further investigated via 

adequate proxies.  



161 

 

Our REE data is consistent with the Sr isotope profile change from CI-2 to CI-3 (Fig. 

2), as preferential dissolved influx from carbonate sources into restricted settings can also 

cause the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios decrease and [Sr] increase. The decrease of the 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios could 

also be a result of syn-sedimentary hydrothermalism, but the epicontinental setting and lack of 

petrographic evidence argue against that. The positive anomalies are mainly observed at the 

basin border close to the eastern Araçuaí orogen (Sections HV and FAS, Fig. 1) or the Sete 

Lagoas High (Section SL; Fig. 1), where 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios are locally more variable and more 

radiogenic (Guacaneme, 2015; Paula-Santos et al., 2017). Rather than hydrothermalism, these 

positive Eu anomalies could be a local contribution of Eu
2+

 from feldspar rich sources 

(Frimmel, 2010). 

The Ce/Ce* values from the CI-3 deeper settings are also very high, with a mean 

values of 1.54 (Table 3). The Ce removal from water column is too slow compared to water 

mixing by circulation, so that the Ce/Ce* values are not an instant picture of the environment, 

but rather an integrated record of a water mass evolution (German and Elderfield, 1990). So 

the progressive increase in the Ce positive anomaly from the lower to the upper CI may not 

reflect a more anoxic environment, but a progressive concentration of soluble Ce
3+

 in the 

bottom waters due to a constant anoxic state (Elderfield and Greaves, 1981; German and 

Elderfield, 1990; Bau et al. 1996, Lawrence and Kamber, 2006). We interpret the Ce data as 

lack of oxygenation of bottom waters and lack of mixing between upper and lower water 

layers of the basin due to inefficient circulation. This probably resulted in a stratified water 

column and as restriction took place at the CI-2/3 transition, anoxic early diagenetic 

conditions that probably led to preservation of organic matter through the basin and 

methanogenesis in shallower areas. This scenario is recorded in the ?
13

C positive excursions 

both in carbonate and organic matter, reaching values up to +16 and -13‰, respectively, in 

the upper Sete Lagoas, Serra de Santa Helena and Lagoa do Jacaré formations (Iyer et al., 

1995; Santos et al., 2000; Alvarenga et al., 2007; 2014; Misi et al., 2007; Vieira et al., 2007; 

Martins and Lemos, 2007; Paula-Santos et al., 2017), although CI-3 lacks organic-rich 

deposits. Alternatively, the absence of negative Ce anomalies could derive from leaching of 

clay minerals during dissolution procedures (Tostevin et al., 2016a). However, we have 

screened our samples to consider only the ones free from contamination of shale. The 

%CaCO3 of the carbonate samples from this study are also within the >85% threshold for 

reliability defined by Tostevin et al. (2016a), especially samples from CI-3 that are very pure 

limestones with detrital proportion in the rock volume lower than 3%.  



162 

 

Finally, we note that CI-3 sections located either at the border of the basin (Sections 

HV, LJ, FAS, Fig. 1) or the Sete Lagoas High (Section SL; Fig. 1) display lower La and Ce 

anomalies and more positive Eu and Gd anomalies (Table 3; Fig. 3c and d), with exception of 

some samples from HV section. We interpret this as a local continental freshwater input 

derived from feldspar rich rocks. This input was probably very limited, enough to attenuate 

the La/La* and Ce/Ce* values but have no effect on the LREE/HREE fractionation as the 

(Nd/Yb)n and (Pr/Yb)n mean values are equal (0.73) or even slightly lower (0.58) than the SC 

and MT mean values (Table 3).   

 

5.3. Ce as redox state proxy of seawater at the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary 

 

Several studies point to a second stage of oxygenation of the ocean and atmosphere 

between 800-542 Ma which could be the driving force for the appearance of complex life 

forms on Earth (e.g. Fike et al., 2006; Canfield et al., 2007; McFadden et al., 2008; Ling et al., 

2013). Intermittent oxygenation of deep ocean waters is also a featured observed (Canfield et 

al., 2008; Scott et al. 2008). The oxygenation events in Oman (Fike et al., 2006) and in South 

China (McFadden et al., 2008; Ling et al., 2013) coincide with a C isotope negative excursion 

in the carbonate rocks therein. However, the redox state of ocean and the rise of atmospheric 

O2 levels during Ediacaran times remain controversial, as different redox proxies suggest 

distinct seawater conditions (Johnston et al., 2013). 

The Ce anomaly is one of the proxies used as seawater redox state across the 

Proterozoic due to the behaviour of this element in aquatic systems. Archean, 

Paleoproterozoic, and most Neoproterozoic biochemical sediments display no negative Ce 

anomalies what is interpreted as lack of sufficient dissolved oxygen in seawater to oxidize Ce 

(Derry and Jacobson, 1990; Shimizu et al., 1990; Danielson et al., 1992; Bau and Möler, 

1993; Kamber and Webb, 2001; Van Kranendonk et al., 2003; Bolhar et al., 2004). Ling et al. 

(2013) report negative Ce anomalies in shallow water carbonates from Dengying and 

Yanjiahe formations, South China that coincides with diversification of the fossil assembly of 

the units. The Ce/Ce* values as low as 0.4 (similar to modern ocean levels) were interpreted 

as an oxidation event of seawater shallow realm linked to the rise of atmospheric oxygen 

levels at the Ediacaran-Cambrian limit, which was possibly the driving force of life radiation. 

The concept used by the authors is that even in the restricted Black Sea the water column is 

oxidized up to ~150 m depth by interplay with the present atmosphere, so that the seawater 

yields Ce/Ce* values around 0.55 (Chester, 1990; Luther et al., 1991). Therefore, Ling et al. 



163 

 

(2013) claim that the Ce negative anomalies in carbonate facies deposited in depths shallower 

than 150 m reflect the oxic state of the water column and that the atmospheric O2 levels may 

have been similar to present day at the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary. Here we apply the 

same concept used by Ling et al. (2013) to test the redox state of the São Francisco basin 

seawater at the Ediacaran-Cambrian limit. The age constrain is based on the presence of the 

index fossil Cloudina sp. in the CI-2 interval (Warren et al., 2014) that presumably lived 

between 550-542 Ma (Grotzinger et al., 2000), and on the maximal depositional age of 560 

Ma obtained by U-Pb detrital zircon dating in the upper CI-3 (Paula-Santos et al., 2015). 

The shallower sections of this work are the SC composed by carbonates with cross 

stratification and truncated lamination positioned at the CI-2, and the oolitic LJ section and 

the FAS section composed of dark carbonates with intraclastic layers, both positioned at the 

CI-3. We have excluded the SJL section from this assessment as the rapid sea level rise 

during transgression could lead to variations in the Ce/Ce* values due to differences in depth 

of the carbonate precipitation (Ling et al., 2013). No negative Ce anomaly is observed in the 

three sections, but rather slightly to moderate positive anomalies (Table 3). So the Bambuí 

Group carbonate rocks do not record the oxygenation of the shallow water column at the 

Terminal Proterozoic.  

Nevertheless, we understand that the Ce/Ce* values are not the adequate proxy for 

such task. Ce and the other lanthanides concentrations of biochemical sediments are highly 

equilibrated with bottom waters during early diagenesis (Haley et al., 2004) and the Ce/Ce* 

values likely reflect the redox state in the water/sediment interface (Elderfield and Greaves, 

1981; German and Elderfield, 1990; Bau et al. 1996, Lawrence and Kamber, 2006). 

Oxygenation of deeper waters in the modern ocean occurs mainly by transportation of the 

upper oxic water layers to the bottom via circulation processes (German and Elderfield, 

1990). In the case of the São Francisco basin, the shallow intracontinental setting probably 

resulted in low thermohaline circulation efficiency, further diminished by restriction and 

stagnancy during the CI-3 stage (Paula-Santos et al., 2017). This probably prevented transport 

of possible upper oxidized water layers to the bottom, resulting in constant positive Ce 

anomalies. As the existence of any oxidized layer in the water column cannot be tested, we 

conclude that the Ce/Ce* record of the Bambuí Group reflects solely the redox state of bottom 

waters both in deep and shallow environments, following what is proposed in previous works 

about Ce in aquatic systems and sediments (Elderfield and Greaves, 1981; German and 

Elderfield, 1990; German et al., 1990; Bau et al. 1996). Therefore, Ce/Ce* values may not be 

adequate proxies to identify the rise of O2 levels in atmosphere in the Neoproterozoic. 



164 

 

The constant anoxia of deep waters in the São Francisco Basin contrast with the 

stepwise intermittent oxygenation of deep waters in the Ediacaran Ocean (Canfield et al., 

2008; Scott et al. 2008). Burial of organic matter is the primary mechanism claimed to explain 

the very positive ?
13

C values in the carbonates deposited after restriction of the Bambuí 

Group that also differs from record of other carbonate successions worldwide (Fike et al., 

2006; McFadden et al., 2008; Ling et al., 2013). Such anoxia might have created a barrier for 

complex life appearance in the basin, as low oxygenated waters might have limited habitable 

space for early animals (Tostevin et al., 2016b). No fossil record of macroscopic organisms is 

currently reported for the restricted CI-3 stage of the Bambuí Group. In fact, anoxic 

conditions and low sulphate supply could have inhibited bacterial sulphate reduction, 

triggering activity of methanogenic archea and driving ?
13

Ccarb values higher than 10‰ 

(Santos et al., 2000; Paula-Santos et al., 2017). 

The evolution of the São Francisco basin in the very core the West Gondwana (Fig. 1) 

is an example of how tectonic settings at the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary may have 

generated unfriendly conditions to life radiation. Although not tested yet, similar scenarios 

may have occurred inside the newly formed large continental masses at that time where 

shallow restricted epeiric seas possibly resulted in inefficient circulation and deep water 

anoxia, and high rates of denudation at the orogens could have provided low dissolved influx 

into the foreland basins.                      

 

5.4. REE as paleoenvironmental identification proxy 

 

The REE concentrations in ancient carbonates are a frequent tracker of secular 

variations in seawater chemistry during the Archean and Proterozoic (i.e. Allwood et al., 

2010; Kamber and Webb, 2001; Kamber et al., 2014; Nagarajan et al., 2011; Ling et al., 2013; 

Zhang et al., 2014; Tostevin et al., 2016b). The “seawater” type shale normalised distribution 

was assigned to interpret early microbial life in ancient marine environments. The fact the 

many terrestrial waters (e.g. lakes, rivers, underground water) present similar REE signal 

brings some problems to this assumption as any water, marine or not, could display the 

“seawater” type REE distribution provided necessary conditions for the REE fractionation are 

available (Johannesson et al., 2006; Hagedorn et al., 2011). Additionally, REE compositions 

have also been assigned to characterize proximal and distal environments (Frimmel, 2009) 

and to identify restriction of basins (Kamber et al., 2004; Zhang et al., 2014). The REE data 

from the Bambuí Group provides further insights on this discussion. 



165 

 

The CI-3 carbonate rocks register the appearance of the “seawater” pattern type in the 

São Francisco basin. The curious aspect here is that it takes place exactly when the basin 

becomes restricted, based on paleogeographic reconstruction, provenance data and isotope 

chemostratigraphy (Santos et al., 2000; Martins and Lemos, 2007; Paula-Santos et al., 2015, 

2017). We discussed that the increased seawater carbonate ion concentration due to low 

silicate and preferential carbonate weathering influx to the basin, possibly combined with 

paleoclimate special conditions, are the causes of this. It raised the concentration of Ln(CO3)2
-
 

in seawater promoting preferential precipitation of the less stable LREE in solution. This 

observation contrasts with previous interpretations that restriction in ancient environments 

was diagnosed through LREE enrichment in biochemical sediments (Kamber et al., 2004; 

Zhang et al., 2014). Actually, REE shale normalised distributions of enclosed bays show a 

similar pattern to the modern ocean with LREE depletion, La and Y positive anomalies 

(Nozaki and Zhang, 1995; Zhang and Nozaki, 1998). Therefore, the LREE enrichment is not 

an unequivocally diagnostic of restriction. 

The studied sections from CI-3 are distributed in an E-W axis along the southern São 

Francisco basin encompassing proximal settings at the basin margin (HV, LJ, FAS sections), 

close to basement high (SL section) and deeper settings (MT section; Fig 1). It is notary that 

the shallower settings have lower La/La*, Ce/Ce* values and Y/Ho ratios (Table 3; Fig. 6). 

But the overall seawater type shale normalised distributions persists, with LREE depletion in 

relation to HREE, La and Y positive anomalies. These smaller differences in the REE patterns 

look similar to the observed in the Japanese coast (Nozaki and Zhang, 1995; Zhang and 

Nozaki, 1998). Although La, Ce, Gd and Y anomalies are less intense in the ocean margin, 

shoreline and enclosed bays, the seawater type signal is still observed in these marine 

environments. Controversially, Frimmel (2009) identified distinct REE normalised 

distributions in different setting from several carbonate successions in Southwestern and 

Central African orogenic belts. The shallower environments display flat type shale normalised 

distributions, whereas the deeper environment carbonate rocks display the seawater type 

distribution (with exception of the Ce anomaly). The nature of the environments are well 

constrained by the author through sedimentology and also ?
13

C values, so the sections indeed 

do display different REE shale normalized distributions. But our data and data from Pacific 

Ocean (Nozaki and Zhang, 1995; Zhang and Nozaki, 1998) clearly show that REE are not an 

unequivocally diagnostic tool to distinguish proximal and distal environments. Perhaps 

differences in the continental input, marine circulation, and in biogeochemical metabolism 



166 

 

processes during early diagenesis can make REE signals from shallower waters different 

among them. 

We find that REE compositions of ancient biochemical sedimentary rocks are useful 

tools to track secular variations in chemical composition of seawater. However, it should not 

be used as an unequivocal nor solely tool to such purpose, as marine environments might 

exhibit differences and similarities among them or with other aquatic settings that may 

misguide paleoenvironmental interpretations.                  

 

6. Conclusions                   

 

- Secular variations in the REE composition of seawater from the São Francisco basin 

are recorded in the carbonate rocks of the Bambuí Group. These changes match the C and Sr 

isotope fluctuations grouped into three Chemostratigraphic Intervals (CI) that record different 

stages of the basin evolution. 

- The lower CI-1 cap carbonate samples are enriched in REE and display flat type 

shale normalised distributions that record a large input of freshwater in shallow marine 

environments. Such freshwater may have been provided by melt of ice sheets. CI-2 carbonate 

rocks record the development of La, Gd, and Y positive anomalies, as a result of a decrease in 

the freshwater input after transgression. Although this CI records the connected stage of the 

São Francisco basin, when biota migration and isotope homogenization with the global pool 

occurred, the overall shallow settings kept the seawater subject to continental influence 

causing LREE enrichment. Curiously, the restriction of the basin during CI-2 to CI-3 

transition marks the development of “seawater” type REE composition with pronounced La 

positive anomaly, chondritic Y/Ho ratios and LREE depletion in relation to HREE. Rather 

than open marine conditions, the CI-3 samples record a significant change in the weathering 

regime on the marginal belts of the São Francisco craton with a decreased dissolved influx 

and preferential contribution from carbonate rocks. This promoted concentration of carbonate 

ions in the basin and subsequent formation of Ln(CO3)2
-
, driving a REE fractionation process 

similar to the modern ocean. Climate changes related to the São Francisco Basin position in 

the West Gondwana continent at the Terminal Proterozoic might also have increased 

evaporation rates and subsequent ionic concentration in seawater. 

- All the CI display positive Ce/Ce* values both in the deep and the shallow realms. 

The Ce positive anomalies reflect bottom water anoxia in early diagenetic environments, 

inefficient circulation in the epeiric sea and consequent stratification of seawater. Combined 



167 

 

with the low nutrient influx, this could have inhibited the appearance of a more diverse and 

complex fauna in the São Francisco basin at the Ediacaran-Cambrian limit.  

- Our data also show that REE compositions are not an unequivocal tool to track open 

and restricted marine settings, or to distinguish ancient shallow and deep depositional 

environments. They are useful proxies of secular variations of seawater as long as they are 

applied in combination with other tools such as sedimentology and isotope data.
